loans.name: Santíago

texts.es:
Santiago de 63 años de edad, es empleado, estudió hasta sexto grado, no continuo sus estudios por problemas económicos, esta casado y es padre de 2 hijos, los cuales ya están casados y tienen su propio hogar, Santiago vive con su esposa y un nieto de los cuales dependen de él, su esposa se dedica a atender una pequeña tienda que tienen en su casa mientras que Santiago se dedica a la crianza de cerdos, a la crianza de animales y a la agricultura (siembra de maíz) desde hace tres años trabajo que lo aprendió de sus padres.

El préstamo solicitado en la institución, es para comprar cerdos de engorde y dos novillas, para poder obtener un mayor ingreso y poder darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.

Santiago sueña con ampliar mas la crianza de cerdos de engorde, para tener mas ganancias con las cuales podrá ahorra para seguir trabajando sin tener un crédito.
texts.en:
Santiago is 63 years old, employed, and has a sixth grade education.  He was not able to continue his studies due to financial problems.  He is married and father of two sons who are married and have their own home.  Santiago lives with his wife and grandson who depend on him.  His wife works serving a small shop they have at home while Santiago works at raising of pigs, animal husbandry and agriculture (corn planting for the past three years).  This is work he learned from his parents.

The loan he has requested by the lender is to buy pigs and two heifers.  The goal is to obtain a higher income and be able to give his family a better quality of life.

Santiago dreams of expanding more breeding pigs, to get more profits with which he can save to keep working without credit.

loans.use: to buy pigs and two heifers, to obtain a higher income and be able to give his family a better quality of life.

loans.name: Filomene

texts.en: Filomene, aged 32, is married to a businessman. She sells foodstuffs and has been in the business for five years. With the loan, Filomene would like to buy beans, sorghum, cassava and plastic items, such as basins, to sell. The profits will be used to increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy more beans, sorghum, cassava and plastic items, such as basins, to sell.

loans.name: Moumita

texts.en:
Moumita is married, 25 years old and lives in a remote village in West Bengal, India. She is a member of Karunamoyee Self Help Group. She lives with her family that includes her husband and a son. Her son is four years old. She is very energetic, hardworking, and enthusiastic and always devotes her time for the betterment of the family.

Moumita breeds fish for her livelihood. Initially, she started her business with a low budget. She gained a little profit. Now there is good demand for fish, so she plans to expand her business, which will help her increase her monthly income. With this loan she will purchase manure, raw materials, food for fish etc.

Moumita thanks the lenders for their support and generosity towards her.

loans.use: to purchase manure, raw materials, and food for fish

loans.name: Elves

texts.es: Elves: Es originario de Waspam, tiene 37 años de edad, casado con 4 hijos menores de edad. Cuenta con una experiencia de 7 años de ser docente. Solicita su primer financiamiento para mejorar su vivienda de tambo de madera y comprar materiales: postes de madera, clavos, madera y cubrir costos de mano de obra. Su sueño es tener una vivienda con las condiciones necesaria y apoyar en el desarrollo humano y profesional de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Elves is originally from Waspám.  He is 37 years old, married with 4 minor children.  He has 7 years of experience being a teacher.

He has applied for his first loan to improve his wood framed home and buy materials: wood studs, nails, wood and to cover the costs of labor.

His dream is to have a home with the necessary conditions and support the personal and professional development of his children.

loans.use: to buy materials: wood studs, nails, wood and to cover the cost of labor.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 32 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 3 years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells rice, sugar, soda, water and maize flour. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy rice, sugar, soda, water, maize flour. This will help Aisha to generate greater profits and also to earn more profits. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to expand to a super market. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aisha who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, soda, water and maize  flour.

loans.name: Kayanja Tusitukirewamu Seed Pjt Group

texts.en:
The group is located in a rural area and is comprised of five members. These include Aloysius, Godfrey, Christopher, Charles and Mary. They are involved in different activities, which include farming, retail, passion fruit farming, produce trading and alcohol brewing.

Aloysius is a married man aged 40 years with seven children, five attending school in different areas. He runs a retail business and is also doing farming as a side business. He started business in 2004 to improve his standard of living and also increase the family income. He acquired the loan to purchase more stock of daily household use items for the retail business. His clients are people from nearby areas and residents. He hopes to build rentals and to expand his retail business.

His challenge is lacking enough capital and people taking a long time to pay their debts. He describes himself as a trustworthy and hardworking man who appreciates the services lenders offer and encourages them to always give their clients a grace period.

loans.use: to buy daily household use items for selling, like sugar, soap and flour.

loans.name: Tushikamane Mbweni Group

texts.en:
Elmina, who is in her early 40s, is married with five children who are still at school.  She has been having a grocery store for five years now.  She works from 8am to midnight daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Elmina's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to buy Kibuku (local brew) beers, sodas, juice and water. She dreams of taking her kids to good schools and to higher levels of schooling.

Elimina will share this loan with her loan group "TUSHIKAMANE MBWENI" who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy Kibuku (local brew) beers, sodas, juice and water.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is 33 years old and lives in the town of Wobulenzi in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 7 years, Sandra has been working hard to manage her restaurant business, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Sandra has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy chairs, tables, table mats, cups, plates and food items. This loan will help Sandra to generate greater profits and acquire items for the restaurant. Sandra hopes that in the future she will be able to own a big hotel. 

Sandra is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sandra who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy chairs, tables, table mats, cups, plates and food items.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Gorret has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, rice, soap, flour, salt, millet flour, posho and cooking oil. 

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, rice, soap, flour, salt, millet flour, posho and cooking oil, and will help Gorret to generate greater profits and earn more profits. Gorret hopes that in the future, she will be able to achieve her targeted goals. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Gorret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, soap, flour, salt, millet flour, posho and cooking oil

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
HELLO LENDERS! Meet Florence, a very hardworking, honest and ever-smiling mother of four lovely children that she really treasures. She is 53 years of age and has been practicing farming for the past six years. She is one of the hardworking women in her village and she offers free advice to young farmers and extends extension services to other farmers in neighboring villages. Florence's primary source of income is milk and egg selling and through these, she has been able to earn an honest income. Florence hails from the Molo area of Kenya, a place blessed with “mother nature” and good conditions that favor agricultural activities.

Florence is a very aspiring woman who wants to protect the future of her children and grandchildren. Hence, she is putting extra efforts into farming so that she can make ends meet. 

Florence is seeking funds to build a greenhouse on her piece of land and with the greenhouse, her crops will have controlled environmental conditions that are ideal for crops to grow healthy. With the loan, Florence will increase her supply of tomatoes and she will be assured of more income.

Being a mother in Africa is very challenging and accessing funds is so hard but with institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, Florence is assured of realizing her dream.

Florence has undergone training on how to save the income generated from the greenhouse and she is much disciplined with finances. She is sure that through the loan, she will have permanent life change.

Profits from the greenhouse will allow Florence to improve her living conditions and assure her grandchildren of a good and secure future.

loans.use: To build a greenhouse

loans.name: Evalyn

texts.en:
Evalyn is a 34-year-old lady married to Boaz and blessed with six children aged between 18 and the youngest, who is three and a half years old. She has been selling assorted cereals for the last 10 years and gets a monthly income of 5,000 KES (Kenyan shillings).

She has applied for her second loan of 7,500 KES from VisionFund Kenya. She will use the entire loan to add more stock of dry maize and beans. She paid her previous loan successfully.

Evalyn will use the anticipated profits to educate her children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: to add more stock of dry maize and beans

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has five children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Harriet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt, mineral water, soap, beers, cooking oil and toilet paper. 

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy juice, Blue Band spread, sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt, mineral water, soap, beers, cooking oil and toilet paper, and will help Harriet to generate greater profits and earn more. Harriet hopes that in the future, she will be able to achieve her targeted goals. 

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Harriet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy juice, Blue Band spread, sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt, mineral water, soap, beers, cooking oil and toilet paper

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has five children who are all currently in school. For the past 14 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her charcoal business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sacks of charcoal, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and improve her status. Sarah hopes that in the future, she will be able to improve on the volume of the business. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 50 years old and lives in the town of NateeteB in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has four children. One of the children is currently in school. For the past three years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her poultry shop for eggs, where she sells eggs and bread. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase her egg stock, and will help Sarah to generate and earn greater profits. Sarah hopes that in the future, she will be able to supply in big numbers. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"

loans.use: to increase her stock of eggs

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. For the past three years, Harriet has been working hard to manage her hardware business, where she sells bricks, cement, hoes and ropes. 

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy bricks, cement, hoes and ropes and will help Harriet to generate greater profits and standard growth. Harriet hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business. 

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Harriet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"

loans.use: to buy bricks, cement, hoes, and ropes

loans.name: Ekomefeemo 3 Group

texts.en:
The three members are part of the group called Ekomefeemo 3, who average 36 years of age and two children each. The women live for the most part in traditional families in Teshie, a working-class district in Accra. They are on their sixth loan with the microfinance institution ID Ghana to meet the needs of their customers.

Gladys, who is standing on the left in the photo, sells cooking utensils. With her loan, she intends to purchase more cooking utensils from the big market and sell to her customers in the community and its environs. 

She will make a good monthly profit that will in part be used to pay back the loan with interest. The other part will go toward her savings and reinvestment.

loans.use: to purchase more cooking utensils to sell to her customers.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 26 years old, single and a hard-working man who supports no one at the moment. He has been in the transport business for the last three years and gets a monthly income of KES 7,000.

He has applied for his second loan of KES 5,000 from VisionFund Kenya which he will use to buy spare parts to repair his motorcycle. He paid his previous loan successfully.

George will use the anticipated profits to provide for the family's basic needs and in future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Ruhorwe Group

texts.fr:
Jacques  fait partie du groupe  Ruhorwe  et  habite à  Bubanza. Il a 33 ans et est mariée à Alice, une commerçante. Ensemble ils ont 1 enfant de 8 ans. 


Il  fait le commerce de  boutique (vente d’unités téléphoniques, housing des téléphones portables, batteries des téléphones portables,… et exploite un salon de coiffure  depuis  1 an. 

Il est à son deuxième  crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  des téléphones portables, des chargeurs de batteries des téléphones portables,... à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait  avoir une boutique  et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Jacques is part of the Ruhorwe group, and lives in Bubanza. He is 33 years old and is married to Alice, a shopkeeper. Together they have one eight-year-old child.

He runs a shop selling telephone units, housing for mobile phones, mobile phone batteries, ..., and has been operating a hair salon for one year. 

He is on his second loan with Turame. With the Kiva credit loan, he will increase his working capital and buy mobile phones, battery chargers for mobile phones, ... for resale, to earn more. 

In coming years, he would like to have his own shop and ensure his children's education.

loans.use: increase his working capital and buy mobile phones, battery chargers for cell phones, ... for resale, to earn more.

loans.name: Arati

texts.en:
Arati lives in Nandakumarpur village, West Bengal, with her husband, three sons and a daughter-in-law. The family’s major occupation is agriculture. They cultivate paddy. They work really hard to run their family, as their income is not adequate to maintain it.
 
Arati is a member of Chanchala Self-Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO. She has taken a loan to buy fertilizer previously in order to have a high quality harvest from her rice farm and repaid it on time.

She is requesting a new loan to buy a tractor. She is thankful to the lenders for this loan.

loans.use: to buy a tractor

loans.name: Rebati

texts.en:
Rebati lives in Mahabbatnagar village in the South 24 Paraganas district, West Bengal. As the river flows close to the village, the area has mostly agricultural land and the major plantation is a betel plantation.

She is 20 years old. Rebati is a tough, confident woman with a strong willpower. She is married and has a daughter. She has a betel leaf farm. Her husband is also helping Rebati in her business.

Rebati has been associated with the local NGO “Sabuj Sangha” and in the past, has taken loans and successfully repaid the loans every time. This time she is requesting a loan of INR 30,000 to prepare a new betel vine plantation. She will use the money to purchase bamboo, wood, string, nails, saplings, manure, pesticide etc. She hopes this will improve her income. She wants to save enough for her daughter’s education and for her future.

loans.use: to purchase bamboo, wood, string, nails, saplings, manure, and pesticide

loans.name: Pratima

texts.en:
Pratima is a member of Mahamaya Self-Help Group. She hails from a rural place called Mahabbatnagar village, West Bengal. Pratima is a very hardworking woman. She is 35 years old, married, and has a son and daughter. Her son is studying in eighth grade and daughter is studying in sixth grade. Pratima grows and sells betel leaves.

She is requesting a loan to invest in betel vine farm preparation, which includes buying wood, bamboo, straw, fertilizer, labor charge and saplings. The earnings generated by this work are the only source of income for her family.
 
This first loan from Kiva will be a big help for her family. It will allow her to strengthen her business so that she can continue to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy wood, bamboo, straw, and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more gari for resale.

loans.name: Anthere

texts.en: Anthere is a businessman. His wife sells clothes and she has been working for the past 10 years. With the loan, Anthere would like to buy more sorghum and bean for sale. The profit from the business will be used to provide food for the family.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum and beans to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe Benkadi est constitué de six (6) femmes  toutes mariées et vie majoritairement dans des ménages polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne  d’âge 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kalaban-coura l’un des quartiers de Bamako. Elles se sont connues à travers des tontines dans le quartier et  leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font le commerce,  tel que la vente de condiments (tomate,  choux, piments…).  Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de rejoindre  Soro Yiriwaso   et sont à leur 1ier   prêt en prêt solidaire.
Madame Awa (femme arrêtée à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des condiments (tomates, choux, piments…) à Kalaban-coura. Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 2 corbeilles de tomates, 2 sacs de choux et 2 sacs de piments. Elles s’approvisionnent  à  Médine. La revente s’effectue à Kalaban-coura au comptant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Awa compte réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour satisfaire les petits besoins de ses enfants et investir le reste dans ses activités. Madame compte beaucoup sur le partenariat  de Soro Yiriwaso pour l’atteinte de ses objectifs qui est l’élargissement de son activité.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group consists of six women, all married and living mostly in polygamous households. They are on average 38 years old with four children. They all live in Kalaban-Coura - one of the districts in Bamako.

They became acquainted through local tontines (savings group) and their income-generating activities. Members of the group are retail merchants, selling for example condiments (tomato, cabbage, peppers ...). To increase their stock supplies, the group decided to join Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first group loan. 

Mrs. Awa (the woman on the far left in the photo) has a great reputation at selling condiments (tomato, cabbage, peppers, ...) in Kalaban-Coura.

She plans to use this loan to buy two baskets of tomatoes, two bags of cabbage and two bags of chili peppers. She resupplies in Medina. Retail sales are conducted for cash in Kalaban-Coura, to a clientele composed mostly of women.

Mrs. Awa expects to achieve with this loan average monthly profits of 40,000 CFA francs, which will be used to meet her children's small needs, and the remainder will be reinvested in her business activity.

She relies very much on the partnership with Soro Yiriwaso to achieve her objectives, which is to expand her business.

loans.use: buy condiments

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay for weeding and pruning, and purchase fertilizer to improve crop yield.

loans.name: Dambe Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dambé est composé  majoritairement de femmes monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 35ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kalaban-Plateau l’un des quartiers de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de, friperies, légumes, couches d’enfants et mayonnaises. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1èr cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mariam (femme debout l’extrême droite sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des friperies de meilleures qualités. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 2 balles de friperies en gros à Médine. La revente se fait en détail à Kalaban-coura à une clientèle mixte. Madame Mariam espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité. Elle a pour objectif d’acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans cette relation avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The Dambé group is composed predominantly of monogamous women. They are on average 35 years old with four children. They all live in Kalaban-Plateau, one of the neighborhoods of Bamako and became acquainted through neighborhood ties.

Group members are small retail merchants, selling used clothing, vegetables, baby diapers and mayonnaise. In order to increase their stock-in-trade, the group decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are in their first group loan cycle.

Mrs. Mariam (the woman standing at the far left in the photo) has a great reputation in selling quality second-hand clothes. She intends to use her loan to buy wholesale two bales of used clothing in Medina. Retail sales are conducted in Kalaban-Coura to a mixed clientele.

Mrs. Mariam hopes to achieve with this loan average monthly profits of 45,000 CFA francs that will be reinvested in the business. Her objective through this relationship with Soro Yiriwaso is to buy a plot of land for residential use.

loans.use: buy used clothing

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal appreciates the previous loan. She operates a charcoal selling business and sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in her business area.
 
With the 40,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, pure water, and biscuits to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, eggs, and butter to expand her business.

loans.name: Dalicio

texts.es: Dalicio: Es originario de Waspam, tiene 45 años de edad, casado con 6 hijos: 3 mayores de edad y 3 adolecentes que cursan su primaria y secundaria. Tiene una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda. Con el propósito de reducir el hacinamiento, solicita su primer financiamiento para mejorar su vivienda de tambo de madera y comprar materiales: postes de madera, clavos, madera y cubrir costos de mano de obra. Su sueño es tener una vivienda con las condiciones necesaria.
texts.en: Dalicio is a native of Waspam. He is 45 years old, married and has six children — three adults and three school age. He runs a small convenience store out of his home. With the goal of reducing overcrowding, he is requesting his first loan to make improvements to his wooden home, purchasing materials such as wooden posts, nails and wood, and paying for labor. His dream is to have a home with the needed conditions.

loans.use: to make home improvements.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de quatre  femmes, les membres du groupe Danaya sont toutes  mariées et vie dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne  d’âge 35 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Kalaban-coulouba l’un des quartiers de Bamako. Elles se sont connues à travers des tontines dans le quartier et  leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe mènent  des activités génératrices de revenu  différent, notamment la vente d’oignons et  charbon du bois. Dans  le souci d’élargir et d’agrandir   leurs activités, elles ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leurs  5ème   prêts  en solidaire.
Madame Sitan (femme assise en 2ème position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo) a une bonne notoriété, car  l’oignons et un légume très prises par les femmes dans le marché de Kalaban-coulouba. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 10 sacs d’oignons. Elles s’approvisionnent à Médine.  Elle mène ses activités au comptant  à Kalaban-coulouba  à une clientèle de femmes. Madame Sitan compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen de 82 500 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour satisfaire son besoin et investir le reste dans son activité. Madame a pour objectif de fidéliser  ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’en profiter beaucoup de prêt.
texts.en:
Consisting of four women, the members of the Danaya group are all married and live in monogamous households. They are on average 35 years old with five children. They all live in Kalaban-Coulouba, one of the neighborhoods of Bamako. They met through local tontines (savings group) and their income-generating activities.

Group members conduct different income-generating activities, including selling onions and charcoal. To broaden and expand their activities, they decided to call upon Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fifth group loan.

Mrs. Sitan (the woman sitting in second position from left to right in the photo) has a good reputation because onions are a much appreciated vegetable by women in the Kalaban-Coulouba market.

She intends to use her loan to buy 10 bags of onions. She resupplies in Medina, and conducts her sales for cash in Kalaban-Coulouba, to a clientele of women.

Mrs. Sitan expects to achieve with this loan average profits of 82,500 CFA francs per month, which will be used to satisfy her needs, and to reinvest the remainder  in her business activity. She aims to maintain this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso to continue benefiting from credit loans.

loans.use: buy condiments

loans.name: Jomary

texts.es: Jomary: Es una señora amable, originaria de Waspam, tiene 31 años de edad, madre soltera de una niña de 2 años. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos desde hace 8 años estableció una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda de tambo de madera. Solicita su primer financiamiento para comprar mercadería: chiverías, granos básicos, sopas instantáneas, huevos, entre otros productos. Su sueño es tener un negocio prospero.
texts.en: Jomary is a friendly woman who is a native of Waspam. She is a 31-year-old single mother with a 2-year-old daughter. With the goal of having her own source of income, eight years ago she set up a small convenience store in her wooden home. She is requesting her first loan to purchase merchandise such as snacks, basic grains, instants soups, eggs and other products. Her dream is to have a prosperous business.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise such as snacks, basic grains, instant soups, eggs and other products.

loans.name: Agustina

texts.es: Agustina: Es originaria de Waspam, tiene 49 años de edad, casada con 8 hijos: 3 son mayores de edad y 5 adolescentes que estudian su secundaria. Trabaja en el gobierno regional. Con el propósito de reducir el hacinamiento solicita su segundo financiamiento para construir un anexo de tambo de madera, el cual será utilizado como cuarto para sus hijos. Su sueño es tener una vivienda con las condiciones necesaria y apoyar en el desarrollo humano y profesional de sus hijos.
texts.en: Agustina is a native of Waspam. She is 49 years old, married and has eight children — three adults and five in school. She works for the regional government. With the goal of reducing overcrowding in her home, she is requesting her second loan to build a wooden attachment to her home that she would use as a bedroom for her children. Her dream is to have a home with the needed conditions and to support her children's personal and professional development.

loans.use: to build an attachment to her wooden home.

loans.name: Joice

texts.es: Joice: Es una señora amable, originaria de Waspam, madre soltera de 2 adolescentes que estudian su primaria. Con el propósito de brindarles a sus hijos una vivienda digna y segura, solicita su segundo financiamiento para construir poco poco  su vivienda de concreto, comprar 250 bloques. Su sueño es establecer un negocio en su vivienda.
texts.en: Joice is a friendly woman and a native of Waspam. She is a single mother with two children in elementary school. With the goal of providing her children with a respectable and safe home, she is requesting her second loan to purchase 250 cinder blocks as she little by little builds a concrete home. Her dream is to establish a business in the home.

loans.use: to purchase 250 cinder blocks.

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de sept femmes, les membres du groupe Horonya sont majoritairement mariés dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont une moyenne  d’âge de 44 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Kalaban-coulouba  de Bamako. Elles se sont connues à travers des liaisons de parenté, de voisinage et  de leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font la vente des friperies, des savons et condiments. Dans  le souci de constituer leurs stocks de vente, les membres du groupe ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leur  5ème cycle de  prêt  solidaire.
Madame Bintou (femme assise en 4ème position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse de friperies de meilleures qualités. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 6 balles. Elles s’approvisionnent en friperies à Médine. La revente se fait au comptant ou à crédit en ambulant et parfois par commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement  de femmes. Madame Bintou compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 150 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour assurer les soins de santé des enfants. Elle a pour objectif d’augmenter le volume de son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Consisting of seven women, the members of the Horonya group are mostly married in monogamous households. They are on average 44 years old with four children. They all live in the Kalaban-Coulouba neighborhood in Bamako. They became acquainted through kinship, neighborhood ties and their income-generating activities.

Group members sell used clothing, soap and condiments. To build up their sales stock, the group decided to call upon Soro Yiriwaso and are in their fifth group loan cycle.

Mrs. Buchi (the woman sitting in fourth position from right to left in the photo) is a big seller of quality second-hand clothing. She intends to use her loan to buy six bales. She resupplies in Medina, and retail sales are conducted for cash and on credit, as an itinerant vendor or sometimes through orders, to a clientele composed mainly of women.

Mrs. Buchi expects to achieve with this loan average monthly profits of 150,000 CFA francs, which will be used to ensure her children's healthcare. She aims to increase the volume of her business through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: buy clothing

loans.name: Todos Unidos En Busca Del Cambio Group

texts.es:
SANDRA es integrante de este grupo. Ella tiene 40 años. Vive con su esposo. Tiene 6 hijos pero solo 3 de ellos viven con ella. Con SANDRA vive también un nieto. Su hija es madre soltera. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.  
Comenta que su esposo no le apoya normalmente con los gastos del hogar y que solo ella trabaja para solventar los gastos de sus hijos.
SANDRA realiza el trabajo informal de recolección de concha en el manglar a más de  la elaboración y venta de creaciones artesanales o manualidades.
SANDRA a sus 40 años se ha propuesto terminar sus estudios de secundaria en un colegio en la jornada de la noche.
Este es su segundo crédito con Fodemi y recibirá USD $500,00 al igual que los demás integrantes del grupo.
Con esta crédito abastecerá de más productos para elaborar manualidades e implementar su pequeño bazar. Comprando vinchas- moños- aretes- pulseras- novedades y arreglos para fiestas infantiles.
Ella espera en 3 años tener su negocio más grande amplio y novedoso. Donde el cliente se sienta satisfecho de encontrar lo que busca…
La casa donde vive es propia y también destinara un pequeño recurso para su arreglo.
Culmina expresando que FODEMI es una puerta abierta al éxito – ya que ayuda al pobre a poner su negocio y trabajar para darles mejor educación a nuestros hijos.
texts.en:
Sandra is a member of this group. She is 40 years old and lives with her husband. Sandra has six children, but only three of them still live with her. She also has a grandson who is living with her. Her daughter is a single mother. Sandra’s husband works as a fisherman. She says that her husband normally does not help with the household expenses, so she is the only one working to help cover her children’s expenses.

Sandra has an informal business of collecting conches in the mangrove. She uses the shells to create handmade crafts that she can sell. At 40 years of age, Sandra is determined to finish her high school education in the evenings.

This is her second loan with FODEMI. She will receive $500, which is the same amount that will be distributed to the other members of the group. With this loan, Sandra will be able to restock with more supplies for making handicrafts so that she can set up a small bazaar. She will buy headbands, bows, earrings, bracelets, novelty items, and decorations for children’s parties.

Within three years, Sandra hopes to have a larger and trendier business where customers feel that they can find the things that they are looking for. She owns the house where she lives, so she will set aside a small amount of money for repairs.

In the end, Sandra expresses her thanks to FODEMI for opening a door to success that helps poor people establish their own businesses so that they can work and provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: to buy headbands, bows, earrings, bracelets, novelty items, and children's party decorations.

loans.name: Shakilah

texts.en:
Shakilah is 32 years old and lives in the town of Fortportal in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children with none of them currently in school. For the past 2 years, Shakilah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt and mineral water.

To help expand her business, Shakilah has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt and mineral water, and will help Shakilah to generate greater profits and improve standards of living. Shakilah hopes that in the future she will be able to boom the business. 

Shakilah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Shakilah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, posho, soda, salt and mineral water.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is a 44-year-old man married to Catherine who adds additional income to support their family and are blessed with four children. Martin has been operating a retail shop for a period of ten years earning an income of KES 20,000 at the end of every month.
  
Martin is now servicing his sixth loan of KES 100,000 and intends to use the entire amount to buy maize flour, wheat flour, rice, sugar and detergents. He plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for his children and hopes to open another shop in the nearby town.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, rice and detergents to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Kupha

texts.en:
Kupha is a married woman; she lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Kupha has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. she faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in her business.
 
With KES 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kamwenge in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, with one of them currently in school. For the past 15 years, Mary has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Mary to generate greater profits and increase on business. Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to have better living standards. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to Purchase Elsa Clean Cook Stoves for resale to rural communities

loans.name: Gulnazi

texts.en: Gulnazi is a 58-year-old widow, from Rodinauli, Zestaponi district. She has only one 27-year-old son and the family earns a living through agricultural activities. In particular Gulnazi takes care of milk cows and cattle. She sells milk products locally, but the income is insignificant and they live in poverty. Gulnazi has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for starting a trade business but could not secure funding. Her loan request was rejected each time, because the creditors did not find the existing family income to be sufficient to approve the loan. Gulnazi requested a loan from Credo to start a trading business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative by Kiva and Credo. The start up loan program provides start up credit with soft conditions for the country's rural poor, who are regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income and do not have access to credit. With the received credit, Gulnazi will purchase materials for sewing bags and will then start trading. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start up loan, will significantly increase the family's income and the family members will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase materials for sewing bags to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food containers, stoves, and knives to sell

loans.name: Nyevu

texts.en:
Nyevu is a married woman, she lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Nyevu has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. she faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in her business.
 
With the KES 45,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Zaitun

texts.en:
Zaitun is 35 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children who are all currently in school. For the past 7 years, Zaitun has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Zaitun has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy shoes, dresses, earrings and bags, and will help Zaitun to generate greater profits. Zaitun hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her amount of capital. 

Zaitun is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Zaitun who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy shoes, dresses, earrings and bags for resale

loans.name: Msigani Group

texts.en:
Amina is in her early 20s and is single.  She has been running several projects.  Selling fruit, vegetables, sarongs and fabric.  she has been in this  business for three years now.  She works from  8:00am-9:00pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Amina's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy fruit, vegetables, sarongs and fabric to sell to more customers.  One day, she dreams of building her own house.

Amina will share this loan with her loan group "MSIGANI" which has ten members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fruit, vegetables, sarongs and fabric to sell

loans.name: Ishaku Idi

texts.en: Ishaku Idi remembers not being able to pay his children's school fees during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Ishaku Idi, like all Babban Gona members can reap up to 30 bags/hectare and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Ishaku Idi. With this loan, Ishaku Idi is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hauwa Ishaku

texts.en: Hauwa Ishaku is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Hauwa Ishaku joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her  children. Hauwa Ishaku is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Hauwa Ishaku will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Hauwa Ishaku can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Hauwa Ishaku is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Bashiru Haruna

texts.en: Bashiru Haruna remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Bashiru Haruna, like all Babban Gona members, can reap up to 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14, and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Bashiru Haruna. With this loan, Bashiru Haruna is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es: Maribel: Es originaria de Waspam, tiene 35 años de edad, casada con 7 hijos, en edad escolar. Su esposo es docente. Desde hace 4 años estableció su negocio de venta de ropa nueva, en un punto estratégico. Solicita financiamiento para comprar en Managua ropa nueva e interior y en Masaya zapatos y venderlos a precios accesibles en el municipio. Su sueño es tener un negocio prospero y construir su vivienda de concreto.
texts.en:
Maribel was born in Waspam. She is 35 years old, married and has seven children, all of them in school age. Her husband is a teacher. Four years ago, Maribel started selling clothes in a well-located area.

She is requesting a loan to buy clothes and underwear in Managua, and shoes in Masaya. She plans to sell them at affordable prices where she lives. Her dream is to own a prosperous business and build a house made of concrete.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Alhasan

texts.en: Alhasan is a 37-year-old farmer from Gidan Kwabo Wambai. As a Babban Gona member, Alhasan is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alhasan can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Alhasan is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Alhasan said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland. In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Alhasan is on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

With this loan, Bitrus is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sule Dangote

texts.en: Sule Dangote is a Babban Gona farmer from Shawai. Sule Dangote expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Sule Dangote to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Sule Dangote can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Sule Dangote is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Sule Dangote will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Sule Dangote will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Emmanuel joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: . Emmanuel is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Emmanuel will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. With this loan, Musa will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Costance

texts.en:
Costance is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has five children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Costance has been working hard to manage her clothing and shoes business, which sells second-hand shoes and clothes. 

To help expand her business, Costance has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shoes and clothes, and will help Costance to generate greater profits and improve business. She hopes that in the future, she will be able to stock the shop. 

Costance is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Costance who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more shoes and clothes

For the past two years, Lavina has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder, and juice. 

To help expand her business, Lavina has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder, and juice, and will help her to generate greater profits and improve business. Lavina hopes that in the future she will be able to stock the shop. 

Lavina is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lavina who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder, and juice

loans.name: Liney Cecilia

texts.es:
Liney es una mujer muy entregada a su trabajo pues a sus 45 años de edad trabaja incasablemente todos los días de la semana de lunes a domingo en su negocio de producción de alimentos típicos como tamales. 

Madre de 2 hijos de 18 y 4 años que depende totalmente de ella ve una oportunidad de una entidad que le brinda la confianza de tener un crédito para mejorar su negocio y soñar con su fábrica de producción de alimentos y hacerle creer que es posible alcanzar este sueño.

Solicita un crédito para la compra de un molino eléctrico que le reduzca sus tiempos de producción y le facilite su trabajo. 

Con la ayuda de este crédito la señora Liney producirá mas alimentos y le permitirá obtener mejores ingresos para cada día darle mejores oportunidades de vida a sus dos hijos
texts.en:
Liney is a hardworking woman. She is 45 and works every day of the week, from Monday to Sunday, making traditional food such as tamales.

She is the mother of two children aged 18 and 4, who depend on her. She learned about an institution that could trust her with a loan to improve her business and help her to believe that her dream of starting a company can come true.

She is requesting a loan to buy an electrical mill in order to decrease her production times and facilitate her work.

With the help of this loan, Liney will be able to produce more food and will receive a higher income. This will result in more opportunities for her children.

loans.use: to buy an electrical mill and ingredients to make food.

loans.name: María Maribel

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Grupo De Crédito La Unidas Somos Más. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 34 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 16 13 y 11 años, los mayores estudian en colegio y los menores en escuela. El marido es mecánico.
Doña María es una gran madre y esposa que realiza el crédito para ayudarle a su marido en su labor, el tiene un taller de mecánica automotriz, en su taller realiza arreglos de todo tipo, trabaja solo y en ocasiones contrata operarios cuando tiene mucho trabajo por entregar, trabaja de lunes a sábado per si lo llegan a buscar también  trabaja los domingos, en su taller vende líquidos de frenos, latas, pinturas, aceites y otras refacciones necesarias para realizar sus trabajos,  lleva más de 16 años con sus taller con el cual saca adelante a su familia. 
Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar pinturas, liquido de frenos, aceites entre otras cosas que necesita en su taller. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde el inicio y le gusta porque con los créditos ella le ayuda a su marido.  Sus sueños son seguir adelante.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank “Unidas Somos Más” [Together, we are more] meets fortnightly in the Rocafuerte canton. This place is known for its delicious desserts (prepared by locals), which are famous all over the country.

This is where María, 34, lives. She lives in a common-law marriage and has three children who are 16, 13 and 11. The oldest ones go to high school and the youngest one to primary school. Her husband is an auto mechanic.

María is a great mother and wife. She is requesting this loan to help her husband, who owns an automobile repair shop where he fixes all kind of things. He works alone, but sometimes hires assistants when there is a lot of work. He normally works from Monday to Saturday, but also on Sundays if someone needs him. He sells brake fluid and lubricants, offers paintwork, and repairs dents and other vehicle damages. He has had this repair shop for more than sixteen years, which has helped him to get ahead with his family.

She will use this loan to buy paint, brake fluid, different types of oil and other things her husband needs for his shop. María has been a member of this communal bank since it started and she likes it because she can help her husband with the loans. Her dream is to continue progressing.

loans.use: to buy paint, brake fluid, lubricants, etc. for her husband's auto repair shop.

texts.en:
Rahma is aged in her late 20s and has two schooling daughters. She is not married, and both daughters are still at school. She has been a food vendor, and also sells Muslim types of clothes, for three years now. She works from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.  

This will be Rahma's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to buy cooking pans, new charcoal stoves and food cooking ingredients. She dreams of owning a hotel.

Rahma will share this loan with her loan group, "NYOTA NJEMA," which has 13 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy cooking pans, new charcoal stoves and food cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Yessica Carolina

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Grupo De Crédito La Unidas Somos Más. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.
En este lugar vive la señora Yessica, tiene 34 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 13, 12 y 10 años, ella está por dar a luz su cuarto hijo, los mayores estudian en colegio y los menores en escuela. El marido trabaja en una camaronera.
Doña Yessica con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo y zapatos, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes cuando necesitan de alguna prenda, ella deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Lleva más de tres años con este negocio el cual le deja muy buenos ingresos.
Este crédito es para comprar zapatos y ropa de todo tipo. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace 4 ciclos y le gusta porque los créditos son muy necesarios para ella. Sus sueños son tener a su bebé.
texts.en:
In the canton of Rocafuerte, the members of the credit group Unidas Somos Más [United, We Are Stronger] meet biweekly. This place is known for its delicious sweets, which are prepared by locals and are renowned throughout the country. 
Yessica lives here in Rocafuerte; she is 34 years old and  has a common law marriage from which she has three children aged 13, 12, and 10. She is about to give birth to her fourth child. The older children go to high school and the younger children are in elementary school.  Her husband works on a shrimping boat. 
In order to earn some money and help her husband with the household expenses, Yessica sells clothes and shoes, both door-to-door and from her home, where customers go when they need something. She gives her customers credit and collects biweekly. She has been doing this business for more than three years and she makes a very good income. 
This credit is to buy shoes and clothes of all kinds. She has been in this credit group for the last 4 cycles, and she likes it because she really needs the loans. Her dream is to have her baby.

loans.use: to buy shoes and clothes.

loans.name: Yahuza

texts.en: Yahuza remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Yahuza, like all Babban Gona members,  can yield up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty” expressed Yahuza.   With this loan, Yahuza is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 30-year-old farmer from Kwakwa.  As a Babban Gona member, Ali, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Ali can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ali is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ali said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Jabiru, Aziza, and Isari, and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Tsahiro

texts.en: Tsahiro remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Tsahiro, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Tsahiro  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Tsahiro   With this loan, Tsahiro is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Muhammadu

texts.en: Muhammadu is a 45-year-old farmer from Kwakwa.  As a Babban Gona member, Muhammadu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Muhammadu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Muhammadu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Muhammadu said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Fahat, Saifullahi, and Abdulaziz, and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Dildakul

texts.ru: Дилдакуль, 45 лет, замужем, мать 4 детей. На протяжении 16 лет занимается животноводством и полеводством, мастер в своем деле. По хозяйству активно помогает вся семья. Образование у Дилдакуль среднее. Начала бизнес с 3,000 сом (KGS) и достигла больших успехов. В хозяйстве имеет 2 дойные коровы, 5 овец и 1 лошадь. Также есть земельный надел, на 0,50 ГА она выращивает клубнику, на остальной территории малину и другие ягоды и фрукты. В летнее время года, Дилдакуль нанимает односельчан для сбора урожая, который продает оптовым покупателям из Казахстана. Зимой занимается продажей молока. Так как начался второй сезон по сбору урожая клубники, Дилдакуль обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку удобрений, селитры и для прополки клубники. На доходы от кредита Дилдакуль хочет расширить свое хозяйство, а также приобрести авто для своей семьи, оно необходимо как для личного пользования, так и для бизнеса.
texts.en: Dildakul, 45 years old is married and has four children. For 16 years she has been raising livestock and growing produce. She excels at her work. Her entire family actively helps out. Diladakul has received secondary education. She launched her business with a starting capital of 3,000 KGS and has been very successful. Her farm now includes two dairy cows, five sheep and one horse. She also has a land plot; she grows strawberries on 0.5 ha [1 acre] of her land and uses the rest to grow raspberries and other berries and fruits. During the summer season, Dildakul hires people from her village to help with harvesting and then sells her produce to wholesalers. In winter she sells milk. Since the second strawberry harvest just began, Dildakul has applied to the Bai Tushum microfinance association for a loan in the amount of 50,000 KGS to buy fertilizers such as niter [potassium nitrate] and to pay for weeding. Dildakul would like to use the resulting revenues to expand her farm. She also plans to buy a car for her family, which is needed both for personal use and for her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and nitre to grow eco-friendly strawberries in order to earn a bigger profit and buy a car for her family.

loans.name: Liliana Del Carmen

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Grupo De Crédito La Unidas Somos Más. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.
En este lugar vive la señora Liliana, tiene 32 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 14, 10 y 3 años, los mayores estudian en colegio y escuela. El marido es agricultor.
Doña Liliana es una muy buena madre y esposa que con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta se dedica a la venta de zapatos y sandalias de todo tipo, ella sale casi todas las mañanas por su localidad visitando a sus clientes y  también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes más conocidos, deja a crédito y cobra cada quince días. Lleva más de tres años con este negocio con  el cual le ayuda a su marido a sacar adelante a sus hijos.
Este crédito es para comprar zapatos y sandalias de todo tipo. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace 3 ciclos y le gusta porque con los créditos ella financia su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en: The members of the Credit Group La Unida Somos Mas meet up every two weeks in the Rocafuerte canton. This place is known for its delicious sweets prepared by the local people and well-known in the whole country. This is where 32 year old Liliana lives. She lives in a common-law marriage and has three children, who are 14, 10 and 3 years old. The older ones go to high school and elementary school. The husband is a farmer. Liliana is a very good mother and wife, and with the intention of earning something of her own she sells shoes and sandals of all types. She leaves her house every morning visiting customers, and she also sells at home to her better known customers. She sells on credit and gets paid every two weeks. She has been working in this business for more than three years. With it she helps her husband support her children. This loan is to buy shoes and sandals of all types. She has been in the Credit Group for 3 cycles, and she likes it because she finances her business with the loans. Her dream is to give her children all the best.

loans.use: To buy shoes and sandals.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 30-year-old lady married to Moses and blessed with four school-going children. She has been selling charcoal for the last two years and earns a monthly income of KES 8,000.

Jackline has applied for her second loan of KES 15,000 from VisionFund Kenya, which she will use to buy more stock of clothes for sale. She repaid her previous loan successfully.

Jackline will use the anticipated profits to provide for the family's basic needs.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Alh. Haruna

texts.en: Alh. Haruna is a 60-year-old farmer from Kwakwa. As a Babban Gona member, Alh. Haruna is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alh. Haruna can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Haruna is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Alh. Haruna said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland. In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Alh. Haruna is on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Lawal

texts.en: Lawal remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Lawal, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Lawal  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Lawal   With this loan, Lawal is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past five years, Shamim has been working hard to manage her spare parts business, which sells spare parts. 

To help expand her business, Shamim has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more spare parts, and will help Shamim to generate greater profits and grow big. Shamim hopes that in the future, she will be able to open another outlet. 

Shamim is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Shamim who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette is 38 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, with two of them currently in school. For the past three years, Rosette has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder and juice. 

To help expand her business, Rosette has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy  sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder and juice, and will help Rosette to generate greater profits and have a big business. Rosette hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business. 

Rosette is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rosette who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, snacks, posho, eggs, bread, soda, curry powder and juice

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 40 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has seven children who are all currently in school. 

For the past four years, Justine has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household items. 

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more household items, and it will help Justine to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. Justine hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Justine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Justine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more household items to sell.

loans.name: Bala

texts.en: Bala is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Bala joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Dayyabu, Sahabi, and  Dije,. Bala is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Bala will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Bala can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Bala is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase assorted drinks, pure water and biscuits to expand her business.

loans.name: Parbati

texts.en:
Parbati lives in the South 24 Paraganas district of West Bengal. She is 47 years old, married and has a daughter and a son. Her daughter is married while her son is studying in sixth grade. Parbati studied till fourth grade. 

This family's living depends mainly on vegetable cultivation done by Parbati and her husband. They earn very little from this business, which is not adequate to meet their daily needs.

Parbati is a member of “Nibedita,” which is managed by the local NGO, “Sabuj Sangha.”  She is requesting a loan of INR 20,000 to purchase fertilizer and seeds for the field. She expects that the income will help her expand her current business and pay for the family's food and healthcare.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Ruma

texts.en:
Ruma is 38 years old, living in a community in the Nandakumarpur village in West Bengal. She is married and has two sons. They are studying in 11th and 8th grade. She didn't have access to a formal education but that didn't stop her from learning to read and write.

Ruma and her husband do paddy (rice) cultivation and earn very little. They have always faced a lot of challenges to increase their yield.
 
She is requesting a loan that will allow her to improve the quantity and quality of her paddy cultivation. She will use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizers and to pay labor costs.

Ruma’s happy and enthusiastic personality is something that really characterizes this entrepreneur, and it is reflected in the work that she does on her small farm. Her dream is that her farm would be considered a model of paddy cultivation with a good, high-quality yield for which she works day in and day out as she is sure that this line of work has great economic potential.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers and to pay labor costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more slippers and clothes to expand her business.

loans.name: Rhona

texts.en:
Rhona is 42 years old and lives in the town of Wakiso in the Kampala  region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past six years, Rhona has been working hard to manage her salon, which deals in hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Rhona has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy chemicals, weaves, and braids. This will help Rhona to generate greater profits and increase stock. Rhona hopes that in the future she will be able to set up another beauty shop. 

Rhona is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rhona who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, weaves, braids

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen is 33 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala  region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Allen has been working hard to manage her produce business, which sells beans, maize, and rice. 

To help expand her business, Allen has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy beans, maize, and rice. This will help Allen to generate greater profits and increase her family business. Allen hopes that in the future she will be able to open another shop. 

Allen is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Allen who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy beans, maize, and rice

loans.name: Marion

texts.en:
Marion is 35 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, with one of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Marion has been working hard to manage her poultry business, which rears chickens. 

To help expand her business, Marion has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks, and will help Marion to generate greater profits and improve her savings. Marion hopes that in the future, she will be able to own a large firm. 

Marion is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Marion who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chicks

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, who are all currently in school. For the past 20 years, Agnes has been working hard to manage her fish vending business, in which she sells fish. 

To help expand her business, Agnes has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish, and will help Agnes to generate greater profits and business expansion. Agnes hopes that in the future, she will be able to have a bigger business. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Agnes who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
