Esther is 28 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, and one of them is currently in school.

For the past three years, Esther has been working hard to manage her electronics shop, which sells batteries, flat irons, kettles, wires, bulbs and stabilizers. 

To help expand her business, Esther has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy batteries, flat irons, kettles, wires, bulbs and stabilizers, and it will help Esther to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. 

Esther hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Esther is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Esther who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy batteries, flat irons, kettles, wires, bulbs and stabilizers.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 28 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. 

For the past three years, Susan has been working hard to manage her stationery/soft drinks shop, which deals in photocopying materials. 

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sodas and photocopying paper, and it will help Susan to generate greater profits and boost the business. Susan hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Susan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Susan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sodas and photocopying paper.

loans.name: Rabi'u

texts.en: Rabi'u is a 40-year-old farmer from Kwakwa.  As a Babban Gona member, Rabi'u, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Rabi'u can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rabi'u is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Rabi'u said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Ashuru, Anas,and Sahalu, and in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Ricardina María Monserrate

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Grupo De Crédito Bachillero, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.
En este lugar vive la señora Ricardina, tiene 53 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció y quedo viuda pero de esta relación tuvieron 2 hijas,  una mayor de edad y la menor de 12 años que estudia en colegio, ambas viven en su casa. Ella hace muchos años aprendió corte y confección. 
Doña Ricardina tiene un taller de costura en su casa, allí elabora todo tipo de prendas,  en época de entrada a clase ella está muy ocupada ya que es cuando más trabajo tiene confeccionando uniformes de escuelas y colegios. También se dedica al comercio, junto con su hija se dedican a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, llevan más de 6 años con la venta de ropa y  con sus costuras casi toda la vida, es con su esfuerzo como ella hoy sale adelante ya que esta sola pero les da lo necesario a sus hijas.
Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, camisas, entre otras prendas de vestir. Es socia fundadora del Grupo De Crédito, es la presidenta del banco y le gusta porque en el banco le han dado mucho apoyo para salir adelante. Sus sueños son seguir incrementando su negocio.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Bachillero” meets fortnightly in Tosagua, known for being a dynamic city where most of the inhabitants work in agriculture and raising animals. This is because of its dense vegetation.

This is where Ricardina, 53, lives. Her husband died many years ago, but she had two daughters with him, who live with her. One is an adult now and the other one goes to school. Ricardina learned to make dresses many years ago.

Ricardina owns a workshop at home, where she makes all kinds of garments. When schools start, she gets busy making uniforms. She has worked with this almost all of her life and has also been selling all kinds of clothes, together with her daughter, for more than six years. She has worked hard to get ahead because she is a widow, but she has given her daughters everything they have needed.

She is requesting a loan to buy pants, shirts and other clothes. She is one of the founding members of the communal bank and its president. She likes to be a part of it because she has received a lot of support to get ahead. Her dream is to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts and other clothes.

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah is a 68-year-old married woman blessed with two children. Her husband adds additional income to cater for the welfare of their family.  

Serah has been operating an agricultural business by rearing livestock and raising chickens as a secondary income for ten years. She earns an income of KES 10,000 at the end of every month.

Serah was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now servicing her first loan of KES 20,000. She intends to use the entire amount to buy additional goats, cows and sheep.

Serah plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees to her children and hopes to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy goats, cows and sheep to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 40 years old and lives in the town of Wakiso in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has six children who are all currently in school. For the past 15 years, Maria has been working hard to manage her hardware business, which sells bricks, cement, hoes, and ropes. 

To help expand her business, Maria has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy bricks, cement, hoes, and ropes. This will help Maria to generate greater profits and increase stock. Maria hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another hardware store. 

Maria is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Maria who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy bricks, cement, hoes, and ropes

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en:
Hadijah is 36 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, with two of them currently in school. 

For the past four years, Hadijah has been working hard to manage her salon business, which deals in hairdressing. 

To help expand her business, Hadijah has requested a loan of 3,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more  chemicals, weaves, and tongs, and it will help Hadijah to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Hadijah hopes that in the future she will be able to build rental rooms. 

Hadijah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hadijah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chemicals, weaves, and tongs.

loans.name: Ronar

texts.en:
Ronar is 47 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Ronar has been working hard to manage her charcoal selling business.

To help expand her business, Ronar has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal, and will help Ronar to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. Ronar hopes that in the future, she will be able to supply charcoal in large amounts. 

Ronar is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ronar who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Maclean

texts.en:
Maclean is 32 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past four years, Maclean has been working hard to manage her charcoal business. 

To help expand her business, Maclean has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal, and will help Maclean to generate greater profits and restock more charcoal. Maclean hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up another bar business. 

Maclean is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Maclean who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal.

loans.name: Ya'u

texts.en: Ya'u is a 38-year-old farmer from Gidan Gambo.  As a Babban Gona member, Ya'u is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ya'u can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Ya'u is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Ya'u is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children. Ya'u’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Radjinder

texts.en:
Radjinder is 47 years old.He lives together with his wife and three children. 

For his living he grows rice on an area of 7 hectares. He owns a tractor. Radjinder has a good reputation in Seva MFI. He is a dedicated farmer and always repays his loans on time. 

With the profits from past seasons and a new loan from Seva MFI of SRD 11,000, he wants to buy a second-hand pickup truck. He needs the pickup truck for his farm and can assist other farmers as well. This will provide him an extra income to take better care of his family and pay for the education of his children.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand pickup truck.

loans.name: Faustine

texts.en:
Faustine is 38 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has four children and three of them are currently in school. 

For the past five years, Faustine has been working hard to manage her business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Faustine has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal, and it will help Faustine to generate greater profits and provide essential needs. Faustine hopes that in the future she will be able to buy plots of land. 

Faustine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Faustine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Shalola

texts.ru: Шалола добросовестная женщина. Она родилась в 1984 году. Шалола пережила много трудностей в своей жизни, так как ее муж бросил ее и их 2 детей и женился на другой женщине. После развода Шалола вернулась в родительский дом. Теперь она живет с родителями и 2 детьми. Шалола занимается скотоводством, так как она живет в сельской местности и имеет хорошую возможность для развития данного бизнеса. Она этим бизнесом занимается уже более 10 лет и имеет большой опыт. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 1000 сомони для покупки сено для скота. Она ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en:
Shalola is a conscientious woman. She was born in 1984. Shalola has experienced many challenges in her life, since her husband left her and their two children and married another woman. After the divorce, Shalola returned to her parents' home. Now she lives with her parents and two children. Shalola raises livestock, since she lives in a rural area and has good possibilities for developing this business. She has been involved in this work for ten years and has a lot of experience.

She is requesting a loan of 1,000 somoni to purchase hay for her cattle.

loans.use: to buy cattle feed

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is 40 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has five children who are all currently in school. 

For the past 10 years, Annet has been working hard to manage her business, which sells spare parts. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy shock absorbers, axles and wheels, and it will help Annet to generate greater profits and provide for the family. Annet hopes that in the future she will be able to open another branch. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Annet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy shock absorbers, axles and wheels.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 40 year old farmer from Kwakwa. As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ibrahim can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ibrahim is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ibrahim said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, in 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Ibrahim is on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Tokto

texts.ru: Токто, 54 года, вдова, многодетная мама 5 детей (2 сыновей и 3 дочери), старшие дети проживают отдельно, 3 младших - вместе с матерью. Образование среднее. Начала заниматься сельским хозяйством много лет назад с небольшой суммы в 10,000 сом (KGS). На сегодня в хозяйстве имеет: 2 коровы, 60 овец и 1 лошадь. Также выращивает картофель на 0,70 ГА собственной земли, морковь на 0,50 ГА и пшеницу на 0,70 ГА.  Ежемесячный доход составляет около 10,000 сом (KGS). Прибыль позволила Токто размножить скот в домашнем хозяйстве и тем самым улучшить семейное благосостояние, также увеличить доходы от полеводства. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Токто обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS) на покупку двух голов скота. Доходы от кредита Токто планирует вложить в расширение хозяйства, а также на образование детей.
texts.en:
Tokto, 54 years old, a widowed, and the mother of many children (two sons and three daughters). The older children live on their own, and the three youngest live with their mother. She has a secondary education. She began to engage in agriculture many years ago with a small sum of 10,000 som (KGS). Currently, she has on her homestead: two cows, 60 sheep and one horse. Similarly, she grows potatoes on 0.70 hectares of her own land, carrots on 0.50 hectares and wheat on 0.70 hectares. Monthly income amounts to about 10,000 som (KGS). The profit allowed Tokto to multiply cattle on her homestead and thus to improve the family's wellbeing, and also to increase income from crops.

With the aim of further developing her homestead, Tokto appealed to Bai-Tushum Bank for a loan of 80,000 som (KGS) to purchase two head of cattle. Tokto plans to invest income from the loan in expanding her homestead, and also to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase cattle in order to be more profitable and pay for her children's education

loans.name: Abdulwahidu

texts.en: Abdulwahidu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abdulwahidu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Nasiru,Haruna, and Zulai. Abdulwahidu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Abdulwahidu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Abdulwahidu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Abdulwahidu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu is a 35-year-old farmer from Gidan Gambo.  As a Babban Gona member, Adamu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Adamu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Adamu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Adamu is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children. Adamu’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, pure water and assorted drinks

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past four years, Jesca has been working hard to manage her charcoal business, selling sacks of charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Jesca has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy sacks of charcoal, and will help Jesca to generate greater profits and add stock. Jesca hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Jesca is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jesca who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Grupo De Crédito La Unidas Somos Más. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 40 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 23, 18 y 3 años, los dos menores aun viven con ellos. El marido es comerciante.
Doña María es una mujer que le gusta trabajar y con su esfuerzo darle a su familia lo mejor, ella trabaja en una casa de la ciudad realizando servicios domésticos, pero en sus ratos libres se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo, carteras, bisuterías, entre otras cosas, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Lleva más de tres años con este negocio el cual empezó con el primer crédito que recibió del grupo por lo cual está muy agradecida.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa, carteras y bisuterías. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace 3 años  y le gusta porque los créditos empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
The members of the credit group Las Unidas Somos Mas meet every fifteen days in the canton of Rocafuerte. This place is known for its delicious sweets made locally and renowned throughout the country.

Maria lives in Rocafuerte. She is 40 years old and has a common law marriage from which she has three children aged 23, 18, and three years. The two younger ones are still living at home. The husband is a merchant.

Maria is a woman who enjoys working and through her effort giving the best to her family. She works providing household services for a home in the city, but in her free time she works selling clothing of all kinds, handbags, and costume jewelry, among other items. She gives her customers credit and collects every 15 days. She's been for over three years at this business that she began with the first loan from the group, for which she is very grateful.

This loan is to buy clothing, handbags and costume jewelry. She's been in the credit group for three years and she likes it because she started her business with the loans. Her dreams are to give the best to her family.

loans.use: to buy clothing, handbags and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Egulansi

texts.en:
Egulansi is 47 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married, and has four children, with none of them currently in school. For the past five years, Egulansi has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household items. 

To help expand her business, Egulansi has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy drinks and other items, and will help Egulansi to generate greater profits and increase the number of customers. She hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another branch in bunga. 

Egulansi is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Egulansi who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy drinks and other items

loans.name: Gulzat

texts.ru: Гулзат 44 года, замужем, имеет 3 детей. Образование-среднее, с 1996 года года занимается сельским хозяйством- животноводством и полеводством. Супруг Гулзат помогает по хозяйству, а также предоставляет услуги пастуха. На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве Гулзат есть 2 дойные коровы, 1 бычок, 1 теленок и 2 лошади. Также на участке мерою 0,80 ГА собственной и 0,40 ГА арендованной земли Гулзат выращивает картофель и эспарцет. Но основной деятельностью Гулзат  является продажа молока местному заводу, когда не хватает собственной продукции Гулзат скупает молоко у односельчан, так как домашнее экологически чистое молоко пользуется большим спросом, так как собственной продукции не хватает, Гулзат  обратилась в  Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дойной коровы. Доходы от кредита Гулзат планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья породистых дойных коров, а также в будущем построить дом для своей семьи.
texts.en: Gulzat is 44, married, and has three children. She has a secondary education has been raising livestock and planting crops since 1996. Her spouse helps her on the farm and works as a shepherd. Gulzat currently has two dairy cows, one bull, one calf, two horses, 0.8 hectares of her own land, and 0.4 hectares of rented land where she plants potatoes and sainfoin. Her main income comes from milk sales. When she does not have enough of her own milk, she has to buy it from her fellow villagers. Local organic milk is in high demand and because she currently does not have enough milk, she has applied for a loan with Bai-Tushum Bank for a loan of 40,000 somoni to buy a dairy cow. She plans to use her profits to invest in additional purebred dairy cows and to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow in order to increase sales of organic milk

loans.name: Hindu

texts.en:
Hindu is 30 years old and lives in the town of Ggaba in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past three years, Hindu has been working hard to manage her timber business, selling timber. 

To help expand her business, Hindu has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber and add chicks, and will help Hindu to generate greater profits and increase on profits. Hindu hopes that in the future she will be able to have more birds on the farm. 

Hindu is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hindu who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more timber

loans.name: Sammako

texts.en: Sammako is a Babban Gona farmer from Gidan Gambo. Sammako expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Sammako to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Sammako can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Sammako is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Sammako will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Sammako will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Isiyaku

texts.en: Isiyaku is a 35 year old farmer from Kwakwa. As a Babban Gona member, Isiyaku is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Isiyaku can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Isiyaku is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Isiyaku said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family. Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Isiyaku is on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Zhiydegul

texts.ru: Жийдегул, 37 лет, замужем, имеет 4 детей. С 1988 года занимается животноводством и полеводством. Бизнес начала с 2,000 сом (KGS). На сегодняшний день она успешный фермер своего небольшого хозяйства, а в хозяйстве у нее имеется: 2 коровы с телятами, 1 лошадь, 30 коз и 20 овец. Ежемесячная прибыль Жийдегул составляет 20,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства Жийдегул обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коров для увеличения поголовья скота. На доходы от кредита Жийдегул планирует построить большой сарай для скота.
texts.en: Zhiydegul is 37 years old, married, and has four children. Since 1988, she has been raising livestock and crops. She started the business with 2,000 som (KGS). Currently, she is a successful farmer on her own small homestead, and she has: two cows with calves, one horse, 30 goats and 20 sheep. Zhiydegul's monthly income amounts to 20,000 som (KGS). With the aim of further developing her homestead, Zhiydegul applied to Bai-Tushum Bank for a loan, in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) to purchase cows for expanding her livestock count. With the income from the loan, Zhiydegul plans to build a large barn for livestock.

loans.use: to purchase cattle in order to invest in further growth of her business

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 35-year-old farmer from Gidan Gambo.  As a Babban Gona member, Hassan, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hassan can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hassan is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Hassan is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Meshak and  Obadiah. Hassan’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Christine Jamin

texts.en:
Christine is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past two years, Christine has been working hard to manage her poultry business, which sells chickens and eggs. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more poultry feed and construct a chicken house, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and boost the business. She hopes that in the future she will be able to have more than 1,000 birds on the farm. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Christine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy more poultry feed and construct a chicken house

loans.name: Shamigul

texts.ru: Шамигул родилась в 1977 году. Она замужем и воспитывает 3 детей. Двое из них несовершеннолетние. Шамигул вместе со своей семьей живет на юге страны. Она очень добрая и трудолюбивая женщина. Шамигул занимается купле продажей детской одежды на местном рынке. Она продает все виды детских одежд. Шамигул использует доход от бизнеса для образования детей и питания семьи. Она должна помочь своему брату, так как он болен и ему необходимо лечится. Шамигул не имеет достаточно денег, чтобы помочь брату и поэтому она запрашивает займ на сумму 5000 сомони для покупки лекарства. Она ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en:
Shamigul was born in 1977. She is married and has three children, two of whom are still young. Shamigul and her family live in the south of the country. She is a very kind and hardworking woman who earns a living buying and selling children's clothing at the local market. She sells all kinds of children's clothing and uses her business income to buy food and pay for her children's education. 

Shamigul needs to help her brother, since he is ill and needs treatment. She doesn't have enough money in order to help him and therefore is requesting a loan of 5,000 somoni to buy medicine. She awaits your kindness and hopes for your charity.

loans.use: to buy medicine to treat her brother's illness

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is a 27-year-old farmer from Dogon Awo.  As a Babban Gona member, Rebecca is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets, and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Rebecca can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rebecca is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Rebecca said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Jeonipah and Precious,, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are well educated”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Rogers

texts.en:
Rogers is 38 years old and lives in the town of Fortportal in the Fortportal region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. 

For the past 5 years, Rogers has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, salt, beans, posho (a maize dish similar to grits), soap, salt, bread, groundnuts, and soya flour. To help expand his business, Rogers has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy items to restock his store and will help Rogers to generate greater profits and improve his standard of living. 

Roger hopes that in the future he will be able to expand business.

* Rogers is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Roger who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt, beans, posho, soap, salt, bread, groundnuts, and soya flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more groundnuts to expand her business.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is a 45-year-old woman, married to Kisamu, who adds additional income to support their family. They are blessed with six children. Stella has been operating a grocery stall for a period of ten years, earning an income of KES 8,000 at the end of every month.

Stella was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a neighbor and is now servicing her first loan of KES 10,000. She intends to use this amount to buy cabbages, carrots, potatoes, and green vegetables to sell to her customers.

Stella plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her children and she hopes to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy cabbages, carrots, potatoes, and green vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en: Haruna remembers the starvation his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Haruna like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Haruna,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Haruna expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Haruna is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Dew

texts.en:
Dewanand is very thankful to Kiva lenders for helping him with his rice cultivation. He has repaid this loan fully and on time to Kiva lenders. With the profits of this loan he was able to save some money for his children's tuition.

Dew applied for new support from Kiva lenders and Seva MFI so that he can save more. He approaches another loan of 11,000 SRD to purchase agricultural inputs.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural inputs.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is a hard-working woman. She is 16 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe, in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. 

For the past 3 years, Teddy has been working hard to manage her shoe business, which sells shoes. To help expand her business Teddy has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy shoes and will help Teddy to generate greater profits and educate her child. 

Teddy hopes that in the future she will be able to own a house.

Teddy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy shoes for resale.

loans.name: Kalbyubyu

texts.ru: Калбюбю 60 лет, замужем, имеет 5 детей (2 сына и 3 дочери). С 2004 года занимается животноводством и полеводством, начав этот бизнес с суммы 5,000 сом (KGS). На сегодняшний день, Калбюбю смогла развить своё хозяйство и полеводческую деятельность - в хозяйстве имеется 2 коровы, 2 лошади, 25 овец и 300 тюков сена для скота, которое заготовили сами. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Калбюбю обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 90,000 сом (KGS) на покупку лошадей. Доходы от кредита Калбюбю планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества скота в своем хозяйстве, а также хочет накопить средства на свадьбу младшего сына.
texts.en: Kalbyubyu is 60 and married with five children, two sons and three daughters. She has been working in animal husbandry and agriculture since 2004, a business she started with 5,000 somoni. She wants to develop her business, which currently includes two cows, two horses, 25 sheep and 300 bales of hay for the livestock, which she herself prepared. With the goal of further developing her business, Kalbyubyu has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 90,000 KGS to buy horses. She plans to invest profits from the loan into further increasing her number of livestock as well as to save toward her youngest son's wedding.

loans.use: to purchase horses and invest in her business in order to be more profitable

loans.name: Hiram

texts.en:
Hello world, meet Hiram - a 35-year-old hardworking, honest, and kind-hearted farmer who hails from the Molo area of Kenya, an area that has wonderful weather patterns that favor crop and dairy farming. He is the father of 3 lovely children who he really loves and adores; they are his “heart beat.” 

Hiram is from a very humble background and was raised in challenging circumstances, but this did not deter him from achieving his goal of being successful in life. Hiram has been farming for the past 6 years, but his heart is on dairy farming he really enjoys milking and feeding his animals. Because of unpredictable weather, pattern crop farming is not profitable. This is why Hiram has put all his energy into dairy farming and has been able to sell the fruits of his labour (milk) to his neighbors and nearby markets.

The Molo area has high demand for milk and dairy products, and Hiram, being an enterprising person, wants to take advantage of that. This is why he is kindly seeking a loan of 65000 Kenyan shillings to be able to buy a quality dairy cow. Hiram projects that the cow will give him 15 litres of milk a day, which will comfortably allow him improve his living conditions and be able to repay the loan on time. 

With your lending Hiram is going to improve the quality of his dairy farming and introduce zero grazing in the future. Hiram is very determined and focused and plans that, through savings from accumulated profits, he will be able to open a large dairy shop where he will be selling milk and milk products. With the loan, Hiram’s life will permanently change and he will assure his family a bright future and better living standards.

loans.use: to buy a quality dairy cow.

loans.name: Keturah

texts.en: Keturah is a 25-year-old farmer from Dogon Awo.  As a Babban Gona member, Keturah is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Keturah can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. With access to high quality inputs, Keturah can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. Keturah is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children; Seth,  and  Thamar. Keturah’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.ru: Нургул 54 года, имеет 3 детей. Нургул в качестве дохода для своей семьи занимается животноводством и выращиванием сельхозкультур – картофеля, ячменя и эспорцета на своих 3,70 ГА земли. Стартовав в 1998 году с покупки скота на 6,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Нургул в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 4 коровы, 2 бычка и 2 лошади. Продажа молока, скота и сельскохозяйственной продукции приносит в месяц около 8,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Нургул обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 125,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение поголовья скота за счет покупки 3 бычков. Доходы от кредита Нургул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, а также накопить на будущую свадьбу сына и обучение дочери.
texts.en:
Nurgul is 54 and has three children. She works in animal husbandry and agriculture as the primary source of income for her family, growing potatoes, barley and other crops on her own 3.7 hectares of land, a business she began in 1998 with the purchase of livestock for 6,000 KGS. Thanks to her hard work, she now has four cows, two steers and two horses. Between milk sales, livestock and crops she brings in about 8,000 KGS per month. 

With the goal of further developing her business, Nurgul has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 125,000 KGS to increase her head count of livestock by buying three steers. She plans to invest profits from the loan into further increasing her quantity of domestic livestock as well as to save toward her son's future wedding and her daughter's education.

loans.use: to purchase three steers for further fattening and resale in order to invest in the growth of her business

loans.name: Mario Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Mario Ramón, es padre soltero de 5 hijos de los cuales ninguno está bajo su tutela, labora como vendedor de venta de refrescos naturales en una esquina en la ciudad de León, se dedica a esta desde hace 10 años, inicia sus labores de 05:00 am y finalizándolas a las 04:00 pm de lunes a sábado en este mismo horario, el realiza esta labor para la mantención de su hogar.

Don Mario,  se acercó a Ceprodel a solicitar un crédito el que utilizo  para la compra de láminas de zinc, las cuales serán implementadas en la remodelación y mejora del techo de su humilde vivienda ya que estamos en el período de invierno permitiéndole brindarle una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Mario Ramón is a single father of 5 children, none of whom is under his care. He works as a salesman selling natural drinks on a corner in the city of León, a position he has had for 10 years. He begins to work at 5am and finishes up at 4pm from Monday through Saturday. He works this job to support his home. 

Mario came to Ceprodel to request a loan to use to purchase zinc sheets, which he will use to remodel and improve the roof of his small house. Because it is now winter where he lives, it will help to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase zinc sheets.

loans.name: Sebesse Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de quatre femmes, les membres du groupe Sebessé sont toutes  mariés dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont une moyenne  d’âge 38 ans et  4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier de Kalaban-coro l’un des quartiers de Bamako. Elles se sont connues à travers des liaisons de parenté, de voisinage et  de leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font la vente des habits industriels, des tubercules et des condiments. Dans  le souci de constituer leurs stocks de vente, les membres du groupe ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leur  5ème cycle de  prêt  solidaire.
Madame Marie (femme assise en 2ème position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo) a une bonne réputation dans la vente des habits industriels(prets- porter).  Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 80 complets. Elles s’approvisionnent en vêtements à Médine. La revente se fait au comptant ou à crédit en ambulant et parfois par commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement  de femmes. Madame Marie compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 125 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour assurer la scolarisation et les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The Sebessé group is composed of four women, all of whom are married and living in   monogamous households. On the average, they are 38 years old, with foru children. They all live in Kalaban-coro, a neighborhood of Bamako. They know each other as relatives, neighbors or through their work. The group  members sell commercially produced clothing, tubers [such as potatoes] and condiments. With the goal of maintaining their stock, the group members have decided to reach out to Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fifth solidarity loan cycle.

Mrs. Marie (the second one seated from right to left in the photo) is well known as a vendor of commercially produced (ready-to-wear) clothing. She plans to use her loan to buy 80 outfits. She stocks up in Médine. She sells for cash and on credit, as an itinerant vendor, and sometimes on order, to a customer base composed mainly of women. Mrs. Marie plans to earn an average monthly revenue of 125,000 West African francs, which will be used to provide for her children’s schooling and healthcare.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Zhekshegul

texts.ru: Жекшегул 54 года, мать 4 детей. У нее среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи занимается животноводством, стартовав в 1996 году с покупки скота на 2,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Жекшегул в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 2 коровы, 2 лошади и 13 овец, также 4,80 ГА земли с посевом картофеля, эспарцета и ячменя. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Жекшегул обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 125,000 сом (KGS) на увеличение поголовья скота за счет покупки 2 бычков. Также часть средств Жекшегул направит на строительство времянки. Доходы от кредита Жекшегул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, а также в образование своей дочери.
texts.en: Zhekshegul is 54 and the mother of four children. She has a high school education and works in animal husbandry as the primary source of income for her family, a business she began in 1996 with the purchase of livestock for 2,000 KGS. Thanks to her hard work she now has two cows, two horses and 13 sheep as well as 4.8 hectares of land where she grows potatoes, barley and other crops. With the goal of further developing her business, Zhekshegul has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 125,000 KGS to increase her head count of livestock by buying two steers, as well as to build a temporary building. She plans to invest profits from the loan into further increasing her number of livestock and into her daughters' education.

loans.use: to buy two steers to further invest in her business

loans.name: Isiya

texts.en: Isiya is a Babban Gona farmer from Galadima-Toka. Isiya is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is this ambition that led Isiya to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Isiya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Isiya, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Isiya is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family. With this loan, Isiya will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.ru: Гульназ 40 лет, замужем, мать 2 детей-школьников. Гульназ в качестве основного источника дохода для своей семьи, уже много лет занимается животноводством и полеводством. Благодаря упорному труду Гульназ, на сегодняшний день она имеет в хозяйстве 4 коровы, 1,00 ГА собственной и 1,00 ГА арендованной земли, на которых она выращивает пшеницу, хлопок и клевер, что приносит ежемесячную прибыль в сумме 15,000 сом. Сделав вывод, что данный бизнес рентабелен, Гульназ обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на сбор хлопка и покупку скота. Доходы от кредита Гульназ планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства, а также на обучение сына.
texts.en: Gulnaz is 40 and married with two school-aged children. She has been working in animal husbandry and agriculture for many years as the primary source of income for her family. Thanks to her hard work, she now has four cows and one hectare each of owned and rented land on which she grows wheat, cotton and clover, which brings in a monthly income of 15,000 somoni. Now that she knows that the business is profitable, Gulnaz has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 100,000 somoni to harvest cotton and purchase livestock. She plans to invest profits from the loan into further growth of her business, as well as for her son's education.

loans.use: to harvest cotton and purchase cattle in order to be more profitable and pay for her son's education

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Amos, like all Babban Gona members, can get yield up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income.“In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Amos. With this loan, Amos is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase medicine for her medical expenses.

loans.name: Moureen

texts.en:
Moureen is a hard-working woman. She is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe, in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Moureen has been working hard to manage her clothing business, in which she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Moureen has requested a loan of UGX 900,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes and will help Moureen to generate greater profits and provide for the family. Moureen hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a house. 

Moureen is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase chickens to fatten up, chicken feed, vitamins and to remodel a chicken pen.

loans.name: Emelina

texts.es: Emelina de 36 años de edad vive con su grupo familiar conformado por su esposo y sus tres hijos quienes estudian actualmente, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas, el negocio está ubicado en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas y la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar las necesidades que se le presentan en su hogar, Emelina solicita un crédito para la compra de materia prima como maíz por mayor y cal, para continuar con sus ventas y así darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica sin limitación alguna.
texts.en:
Emelina is 36 years old, and she lives with her family- her husband and her three children who are currently studying. She works preparing and selling tortillas. Her business is located in her home, which is where she makes her sales. With her husband's help, they are able to meet their home's needs.

Emelina is requesting a loan to purchase material goods such as wholesale corn and lime to continue with her sales and be able to give her family more economic stability without any limitations.

loans.use: to purchase wholesale corn and lime.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Joshua, like all Babban Gona members, can get yield up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Joshua. With this loan, Joshua is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase purlin, zinc, blocks, iron blocks, cement, sand and gravel.

loans.name: Habila

texts.en: Habila remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Habila, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Habila is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs,”  expressed Habila. With this loan, Habila is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Kulumkan

texts.ru: Кулумкан 62 года, замужем, все дети самостоятельные и живут отдельно. У Кумушкан средне-специальное образование, она много лет проработала учительницей начальных классов в сельской школе, сейчас на пенсии. В качестве основного источника дохода для семьи, Кулумкан занимается животноводством. Начатое в 2007 году с покупки овец на 10,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство, на сегодня приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. На данный момент в хозяйстве Кулумкан имеется 15 овец, заготовлено 25 тюков сена. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Кулумкан обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 2 бычков для откорма и перепродажи. Доходы Кулумкан планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота, а в будущем планирует купить дочери отдельный собственный дом.
texts.en: Kulumkan is 62 and married. Her children are all grown and live independently. She has a specialized secondary education and was a primary school teacher in the village for many years, though she is now retired. Kulumkan earns the main income for her family by raising livestock. She started her farm in 2007 when she bought sheep for 10,000 som (KGS). Today she earns about 10,000 som (KGS) per month and has 15 sheep and 25 bales of hay harvested. In order to continue expanding her business, Kulumkan applied for a loan with Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 40,000 som (KGS) to purchase two steers for fattening and resale. She plans to invest her profits in additional livestock and to buy a house for her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase two steers in order to invest in her business

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a 36-year-old farmer from Daura. As a Babban Gona member, Musa, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Musa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Musa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Musa said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; solome, meshech,  and  sedrach, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Mero

texts.en:
Mero is a maize farmer from Kurmi Kogi.  As a Babban Gona member, Mero is excited about the opportunity to finally access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Mero can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from her maize farm, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Mero can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I would like to be the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Mero is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en:
Dauda is a maize farmer from Kurmi Kogi.  As a Babban Gona member, Dauda is excited about the opportunity to finally access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from his maize farm, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Dauda can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I would like to be the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Dauda is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Wanki Mairin Group

texts.es:
Está integrado por 3 hermosas mujeres, que se organizaron hace 10 meses para poder acceder a financiamiento y comprar mercadería para sus pequeños negocios y mejorar sus ingresos en sus hogares. Wangki Mairin que en miskito significa mujeres del río, en honor al Río Coco, que se considera el río más largo de Centroamérica que cruza por Waspam y más de cien comunidades miskitas del municipio que lleva el mismo nombre

Silvia: Es la Coordinadora del grupo solidario, originaria de Waspam, casada, tiene 9 hijos: 7 mayores de edad y 2 adolescentes que estudian su secundaria. Desde hace mas de 2 años ha establecido su pequeño negocio de venta de bastimento en el mercado municipal, instala sus productos en la acera, extiende un plástico negro para mostrar las frutas y verduras. Solicita financiamiento para comprar: coco, malanga, quequisque, yuca, limones, pijibay, cebolla, tomates, chiltomas, entre otros productos. Su sueño es tener su propio local en el mercado y apoyar al desolló humano y profesional de sus 2 menores hijos.
texts.en:
It is made up of 3 beautiful women who organized themselves 10 months ago in order to access financing, purchase merchandise for their small businesses, and improve income in their homes. Wangki Mairin is a Miskito term that signifies women of the river in honor of the Río Coco. It is considered the largest river in Central America that crosses through Waspam and more than one hundred Miskito communities of the municipality that has the same name.

Silvia is the coordinator of the supportive group and a native of Waspam. She is married and has 9 children; 7 of whom are adults and 2 adolescents who are in high school. More than 2 years ago she started her small business selling supplies in the municipal market. She sets up her products on the sidewalk and extends a black plastic to show the fruits and vegetables. She requests financing to buy coconut, malanga/quequisque root, yucca, lemons, pijibay fruit, onion, tomatoes, and sweet peppers, among other products. Her dream is to have her own shop in the market and support the human and professional development of her two younger children.

loans.use: to buy coconut, malanga/quequisque root, yucca, lemons, pijibay fruit, onion, tomatoes, and sweet peppers, among other products.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en: Yahaya remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Yahaya, like all Babban Gona members,can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize; more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yahaya  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Yahaya.  With this loan, Yahaya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Saah

texts.en:
Saah is a hard-working woman. She is 18 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe, in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past two months, Saah has been working hard to manage her food stall business, in which she sells tomatoes, cabbages, and greens. 

To help expand her business, Saah has requested a loan of UGX 200,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy tomatoes, cabbages, and greens and will help Saah to generate greater profits and provide for the family. Saah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to add rentals. 

Saah is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, cabbages, and greens to sell.

loans.name: Jamileth Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Jamileth del Socorro, es madre de 2 hijos de los cuales ambos están bajo su cargo y son de edad escolar, labora como estilista en un salón de belleza de la ciudad de León, se dedica a esta labor desde hace 10 años, inicia sus labores de 08:00 am y finalizándolas a las 04:00 pm de lunes a sábado en este mismo horario, el realiza esta labor para la mantención de su hogar y de sus pequeños hijos.

Doña Jamileth, solicito a Ceprodel un crédito el que utilizo para la compra de vitrina, productos de belleza (shampoo, tintes para el cabello, etc.); así lograr brindar un mejor servicio a su clientela con productos de mejor calidad o que le permitirá incrementar su capital de trabajo al igual que su nivel de vida
texts.en:
Jamileth del Socorro is the mother of two children, both of whom are of school age and in her care.

She works as a stylist in a beauty salon in the city of León.  She starts work at 8 a.m. and finishes at 4 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and has been doing this job for 10 years.  She does this work to support her household and her young children.

Jamileth asked CEPRODEL for a loan that she used to buy a display case and beauty products (shampoo, hair dye, etc.).  That way she'll manage to offer better customer service with higher-quality products or increase her working capital along with her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a display case and beauty products

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
Haruna is a maize farmer from Kurmi Kogi.  As a Babban Gona member, Haruna is excited about the opportunity to finally access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Haruna can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from his maize farm, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Haruna can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I would like to be the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Haruna is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Yesenia Gabriela

texts.es: Yesenia vive en casa propia con su compañero de vida,  ella se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia pero sale a vender en el carro que es propiedad de su madre, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos  de los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, clienta solicita un crédito para la compra de frutas y verduras por mayor, para poder continuar con sus ventas y poder tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Yesenia lives in her own house with her life partner. She sells fruits and vegetables; her business is located at her place of residence, but she leaves to sell the goods in her mother's car. With what she obtains from her sales, she is able to take care of some of her household expenses. The client is asking for a loan to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables in order to continue her sales and to be able to, alongside her family, have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy wholesale fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Maria Leticia

texts.es: María de 43 años de edad, ella vive con su esposo y sus hijos, ella posee una tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia, posee mucha clientela con lo que gana de sus ventas y con la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar algunas necesidades de su hogar, María solicita un crédito para poder comprar sopas, arroz, golosinas, refrescos, jabon, detergente, frijoles, etc. para surtir su tienda y asi poderle dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida sin limitación alguna.
texts.en: María is 43 years old and lives with her husband and children. She owns a store located in her place of residence; she has many clients. With what she earns from her sales and with the help of her husband, they are able to take care of some household necessities. María asks for a loan to buy soup, rice, sweets, soda, soap, detergent, beans, etc. to stock her store and, therefore, to give her family a better quality of life without any limitations.

loans.use: to buy soup, rice, sweets, soda, soap, detergent, beans, etc.

loans.name: Saira Yanira

texts.es: Saira de 33 años de edad vive en casa alquilada con sus padres y su esposo, ella posee un bazar cerca de su lugar de habitación desde hace tres años, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas ayuda a solventar algunos de los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, Saira solicita un crédito para la compra de producto como: blusas, zapatos, juguetes, esmalte para uñas, diademas, colas para el cabello, etc. Y así poder continuar con sus ventas y poderle dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Saira is 33 years old. She lives in a rented house with her parents and her husband. For the past three years, she has owned a dollar store close to her home. With the profits from her sales, she helps meet some of her household expenses. 

Saira is requesting a loan to buy products such as blouses, shoes, toys, nail polish, headbands, ponytail holders, and the like, so that she will be able to continue with her sales and give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy blouses, shoes, toys, nail polish, headbands, ponytail holders, and the like.

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en: Dauda remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Dauda, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Dauda  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Dauda. With this loan, Dauda is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Felix Alberto

texts.es: Felix de 34 años de edad  vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos, el se dedica a la siembra de  maíz, desde hace varios años, cuando su cosecha ya esta lista la almacena en los graneros que muestra en la fotografía para luego comercializarlos en los alrededores de la zona, con lo que logar de sus ganancias solventa algunas de las necesidades de su hogar, Felix  solicita un crédito para la compra de  fertilizantes, abonos, herbecidas, controles de plagas, etc. para darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Felix is 34 years old, he lives with his wife and two children. He has been growing corn for a living for the past few years. When his crop is ready, he stores it in the silos that are shown in the photo, until he sells it in the surrounding area. His earnings are used to pay for some of the household necessities. 

Felix is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, manure, herbicides, pest control, etc to give his family more financial stability.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, manure, herbicides, pest control, etc.

loans.name: Enrique Javier

texts.es: Enrique vive en casa propia con su esposa y su hijo, el posee un taller de enderezado y pintura, el negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, con las ganancias que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunas necesidades de su hogar, Enrique solicita un crédito para la compra de material como: pinturas, engrasados, herramientas, etc. y así poder seguir con su trabajo para darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Enrique lives in his own house with his wife and son. He owns a painting and repair shop; the business is located in his place of residence. With the earnings that he obtains from his work, he is able to take care of some of his household necessities. Enrique asks for a loan to buy material such as: paint, grease, tools, etc., and therefore to be able to continue with his work to give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy paint, grease, tools, etc.

loans.name: Hannatu

texts.en: Hannatu is a maize farmer from Tanko.  As a Babban Gona member, Hannatu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hannatu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Hannatu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. My overall goal is to become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en:
Adamu is a Babban Gona farmer from Kuradawa. Adamu expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Adamu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Adamu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Adamu can reap up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14.
In doing so, Adamu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. With this loan, Adamu will be able to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en:
Yahaya is a maize farmer from Auchan.  As a Babban Gona member, Yahaya is excited about the opportunity to finally access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Yahaya can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from his maize farm, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Yahaya can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I would like to be the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Yahaya is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Fátima Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Fátima del Rosario, es madre de 1 hijo el cual está en edad escolar, labora como analista de sistema en unas de las empresas privadas de la ciudad de León, se dedica a esta labor desde hace 7 años, inicia sus labores de 07:00 am y finalizándolas a las 04:00 pm de lunes a viernes en este mismo horario, ella realiza esta labor para la mantención de su hogar.

Doña Fátima,  se acercó a Ceprodel a solicitar un crédito el que utilizo para gastos médicos como es la Compra de medicinas y Exámenes Especiales), lo cual le permitirá recuperar la salud lo más pronto posible de su pequeña hija.
texts.en:
Fátima del Rosario is the mother of one child of school age.

She works as a systems analyst in one of the private companies in the city of León.  She has had this job for seven years.  She starts work at 7 a.m. and finishes at 4 p.m., working the same schedule Monday through Friday.  She does this job to support her household.

Fátima went to CEPRODEL for a loan, which she used for medical expenses such as paying for medicine and special tests.  This will allow her daughter's health to recuperate as soon as possible.

loans.use: to pay for medicine and special tests

loans.name: Shehu

texts.en: Shehu is a 46-year-old farmer from kadanya Biyar.  As a Babban Gona member, Shehu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Shehu can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, as a result of the high quality inputs that he will purchase with this loan, Shehu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked about the future, Shehu said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Inusa, Shafiu, and Ummaru. In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Ruben Ernesto

texts.es: Rubén de 55 años de edad vive con su esposa,  se dedica al cultivo de maíz y maicillo, tiene muchos años de experiencia en el cultivo, adicional a eso tiene un camión  donde hace viajes, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunas necesidades que se le presentan en su hogar, Rubén solicita un crédito para la compra: fertilizantes, abonos, herbicidas, semillas, etc. asi como muestra en la fotografía para seguir con sus cultivos, y poder tener junto con su esposa una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Rubén is 55 years old and he lives with his wife. He has many years of experience growing corn and sorghum for a living, as well as driving a truck. His earnings from work manage to pay for some household necessities.

Rubén is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, manure, herbicides, seeds, etc, as shown in the photo, so he can continue growing his crops and to allow him and his wife to have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, manure, herbicides, seeds, etc.

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Samaila, like all Babban Gona members, can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Samaila. With this loan, Samaila is well on his way to achieving this dream.
