loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Aminta Noemy

texts.es: Aminta de 38 años de edad tiene una tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en casa propia, tiene mucha clientela, con lo que gana de sus ventas y con la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar algunos gastos que se le presentan en su hogar. Aminta solicita un crédito para la compra de mercadería para surtir la tienda como: golosinas, refrescos, granos básicos, huevos, etc. Para darle  a su familia un mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en: For many years Aminta, 38 years old, has had a store located in her place of residence. She lives with her husband and children in her own house and has a lot of customers. With what she earns from her sales she helps her husband pay for some of their household expenses. Aminta is requesting a loan to buy merchandise to stock up her store, such as: sweets, sodas, basic grains, eggs, etc., in order to give her family a better level of life.

loans.use: to buy sweets, sodas, basic grains, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Santos

texts.es: Santos de 58 años de edad vive con su grupo familiar, el es una persona responsable y  muy trabajador, se dedica al cultivo de maiz  y adicional a eso también se dedica a  la pesca artesanal, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar las necesidades que tiene su hogar, Santos solicita un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, semillas, herbecidas, controles de plagas, fertilizantes, etc. para tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Santos is 58 years old, he lives with his family and he is a hard-working and responsible person. He grows corn for a living as well as non-industrial fishing. The money he makes from what he sells manages to pay for his household expenses. 

Santos is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, manure, seeds, herbicides, pest control, etc so that he and his family can have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, manure, seeds, herbicides, pest control, etc.

loans.name: Cristhian Ulises

texts.es: Cristhian de 30  años de edad vive con su grupo familiar, el es una persona muy trabajadora y amable, se dedica al cultivo de maíz y adicional a eso a la crianza de ganado, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, Cristhian  solicita un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, semillas, herbicidas, controles de plagas, etc. Para darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia sin limitación alguna.
texts.en: Cristhian is 30 years old and lives with his family. He is a kind and hard working person who makes a living by growing corn and in addition to that, raises cattle. He sells his products in the various markets found close to his residence. Cristhian is requesting this loan to buy fertilizers, manure, seeds, herbicides, pest controls, etc. This is to give his family a better quality of life without a single limitation.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, manure, seeds, herbicides, pest control, etc.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a hard-working woman. She is 22 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe, in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past two years, Susan has been working hard to manage her clothing business in which she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of UGX 600,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and will help Susan to generate greater profits and personal development. Susan hopes that, in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Susan is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a hard-working woman. She is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past year, Aisha has been working hard to manage her clothing shop. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes, and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and to develop personally. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more charcoal and oil to sell.

loans.name: Aliyu

texts.en:
Aliyu is a Babban Gona farmer from kadanya Biyar. Aliyu is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Aliyu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Aliyu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Aliyu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. 
Aliyu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Aliyu will be able to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Abubakar Alh.

texts.en: Abubakar Alh. is a Babban Gona farmer from . Abubakar Alh. expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Abubakar Alh. to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Abubakar Alh. can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Abubakar Alh. is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Abubakar Alh. will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Abubakar Alh. will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: An Ka Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe An ka ben est composé de femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila commune du Mandé / cercle de Kati et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage.Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de, condiments (aubergines, piments et échalotes). Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Tassiri (femme debout à l’extrême droite sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente de condiments (aubergines, piments et échalotes). Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 5 sacs d’aubergines, 3 sacs de piments et 3 sacs d’oignons à Médine. La revente s’effectue à Kanadjiguila au comptant et parfois en crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Tassiri espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, elle a pour but de prendre en charge les besoins de la famille.
texts.en: The An Ka Ben Group consists of mostly married women living in monogamous households.  They have an average age of 42 and five children.  They all live in Kanadjiguila, in the commune of Mande, in the area of Kati. They met via neighborhood ties.  The group members run small food businesses, selling condiments like eggplant, peppers, and shallots.  To increase their working capital, the group members decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second group loan.  Ms. Tassiri (the woman standing at the far right of the photo) is well-known for the sale of condiments (eggplant, peppers, and shallots).  She plans to use her loan to buy five bags of eggplants, three bags of peppers, and three bags of onions, in Medine.  The resale takes place in Kanadjiguila for cash and sometimes for credit to a clientele of mostly women.  Ms. Tassiri hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA that will be reinvested in her business. Her goal is to take care of her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy condiments.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase material for sewing comforters and other products.

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Adamu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Mudasiru, Saminu,  and  Kadija. Adamu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Adamu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Adamu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Adamu said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Adamu is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is a 20-year-old woman who lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past five years, Nuru has been working hard to manage her tailoring business, which deals in sewed clothes. 

To help expand her business, Nuru has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy items and materials for the business and will help Nuru to generate greater profits and educate her children. Nuru hopes that in the future she will be able to educate both of her children. 

Nuru is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: buy items and materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Augustine Sani

texts.en: Augustine Sani is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Augustine Sani joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Mashan,Monday, and Ahness. Augustine Sani is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Augustine Sani will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Augustine Sani can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Augustine Sani is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Auwalu

texts.en:
Auwalu remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Auwalu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Auwalu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Auwalu is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is an 18-year-old woman who lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past year, Juliet has been working hard, selling clothes and managing her clothing shop. 

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for the shop and will help Juliet to generate greater profits and provide for her child. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to develop her business. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: purchase more clothes for her store

loans.name: Idris

texts.en: Idris is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Idris joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Abubakar, Usaini,  and  Okashatu. Idris is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Idris will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Idris can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Idris said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Idris is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Jolie Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogamiques, les cinq  membres du groupe Jolie ont en moyenne 33 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu au marché de Kanadjiguila. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce d’habits, du bois de chauffage, du jus et de la restauration. Dans le but de pérenniser leur petit commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Maïmouna (femme debout au milieu sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse d’habits. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  50 pièces de pagnes wax en gros à Bamako. La revente se fait en détails  à Kanadjiguila à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Maïmouna compte avoir avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et satisfaire les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en: Mostly married and living in monogamous households, the five members of the Jolie Group have an average age of 33 and four children.  They all live in Kanadjiguila and met through neighborhood ties and their income-generating businesses in the Kanadjiguila market.  The group members run small businesses selling clothing, firewood, juice, and food. To sustain their small businesses, the group members decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third group loan. Ms. Maimouna (the woman standing in the middle of the photo) is a major seller of clothing.  She plans to use her loan to buy 50 pieces of "pagne" cloth wholesale in Bamako. The resale will take place in Kanadjiguila to a clientele of mostly women.  Ms. Maimouna expects to earn an average monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA that will be reinvested in her business and used to take care of her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Uzinduzi Group

texts.en:
Sheila, a businesswoman in her early forties, is not married and has three sons and one daughter. Sheila's kids are at school. For seven years now, she has had a shop selling cosmetics. Working from 9:00 a.m to 3:00 p.m, she is able to make a good profit each month. 

She has taken loans via Tujijenge Tanzania for twelve cycles now. With her previous loan cycles, since repaid, she has improved her shop, restocking more cosmetics. Sheila received extra income which she used to cover household expenses and school fees. She is so happy now because she is able sell more types of cosmetics. In the coming years, Sheila would like to improve her life. She is now requesting a thirteenth loan which she will use to buy cosmetics for her shop. 

She will share this loan with her loan group, Uzinduzi, which consists of four members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for her shop.

loans.name: Usman

texts.en: Usman is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Usman joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for hischildren: Samaila, Dayyab,  and  Bashari. Usman is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Usman will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Usman can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Usman said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family. Usman is not thinking about just this year; he said, In 5 years, he  wants to make more money for myself and my family.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Carlos Humberto

texts.es: Carlos de 34 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus hijos, él se dedica al cultivo ya tiene muchos años de estar cultivando maíz y maicillo, comercializa sus productos en los alrededores de la zona donde el reside, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunas necesidades de su hogar, Carlos solicita un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, semillas, herbicidas,  controles de plagas, etc. y asi tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Carlos is 34 years old and lives in a house that he owns with his wife and children. Carlos works in farming and has many years' experience growing corn and sorghum. He sells his products in the areas around his home. Carlos is able to cover some household costs with money from sales. Carlos is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilisers, manure, seeds, weed-killers, anti-disease treatments and more. This will allow him to have a better quality of life with his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilisers, manure, seeds, weed-killers, anti-disease treatments and more.

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a 30-year-old maize farmer.  As a Babban Gona member, Samaila is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets, and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Samaila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize; more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. When asked, Samaila says he intends to use the increased income he hopes to make from his yield increase, to provide good food and clothing for himself and his family. "Ultimately, I want to provide more money for myself and my family", expressed Samaila. With this loan Samaila is on the path of fulfilling his dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: Oscar es soltero no tiene hijos y vive en La Paz en una casa de larillo y cemento que le pertenece a sus padres Oscar trabaja como chofer y necesita un credito para reparar el motor de su vehiculo ya que recientemente sufrio un choque Oscar es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Oscar is single and has no children. He lives in La Paz in a house built with bricks and cement that belongs to his parents. Oscar works as a driver. He needs a loan in order to repair the engine of his car following a recent crash. Oscar is his household's only source of income and so needs your help.

loans.use: to repair the engine of his car following a recent crash.

loans.name: Nora Maribel

texts.es: Nora de 32 años de edad  vive con su esposo y su hermana, ella se dedica a la elaboración y  vender pupusas, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia  ya tiene mucha clientela establecida, con lo que ella gana de sus ventas y con la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar algunas necesidades que tiene su hogar, Nora solicita un crédito para la compra de maíz, quesillo, chicharron, frijoles, tomates, etc. y asi poder tener una mejor estabilidad económica junto con su familia.
texts.en: Nora is 32 years old and lives with her husband and sister. Nora makes a living preparing and selling "pupusas" (a thick corn tortilla stuffed with cheese, fried pork rind, chicken, or refried beans). She runs her business out of her home and has many regular customers. Nora manages to cover some household costs with her profits and help from her husband. Nora is applying for a loan in order to buy corn, cheese, pork, beans, tomatoes and more. With these items she can enjoy more financial stability with her family.

loans.use: to buy corn, cheese, pork, beans, tomatoes and more.

loans.name: Jose Cosme

texts.es: José de 48 años de edad vive con su esposa e hijos es una persona muy responsable y trabajador, el se dedica al cultivo de maíz y maicillo, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar las necesidades de su hogar, ya que tiene mucha experiencia cultivando maíz y maicillo, José solicita un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes, abonos, semillas, herbicidas, controles de plagas, etc. asi como muestra en la fotografía, para darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica sin limitación alguna.
texts.en: José is 48 years old and lives with his wife and children. He is very responsible and hard-working and makes a living growing corn and sorghum. José is able to cover some household costs with profits from sales as he has a lot of experience in this work. José is applying for a loan in order to buy fertilisers, manure, seeds, weed-killers, anti-disease treatments and more (just like the items shown in the photograph). With this loan, José can give his family more financial stability.

loans.use: to buy fertilisers, manure, seeds, weed-killers, anti-disease treatments and more.

loans.name: Faustino

texts.es:
Faustino es viudo, no tiene hijos que esten a su cargo ya que ellos ya son independientes; vive en casa propia en la ciudad de El Alto.

El Nivel de educación de Faustino es primario, actualmente percibe una renta de jubilación que le otorgan mensualmente.
 
El crédito lo requiere para pagar la refaccion del tumbado de su vivienda que tiene filtraciones

El sueño de Faustino es dejar a sus hijos un lugar donde puedan vivie satisfactoriamente.
texts.en:
Faustino is a widower who lives in his own house in the city of El Alto.  He has no children in his care because they're all adults.  Faustino finished elementary school.  Currently he earns a monthly retirement income.

He needs the loan to pay to repair the ceiling of his house because it leaks.

Faustino's dream is to leave his children a place where they can live successfully.

loans.use: to repair the ceiling of his house

loans.name: Rene

texts.es:
René es casado y tiene dos hijos que están en etapa escolar, viven en casa propia ocupando dos habitaciones con paredes de ladrillo y el piso de tierra, la casa se encuentra ubicada en la zona Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz.
Actualmente trabaja como empleado en una empresa privada realizando todo tipo de tramites trabajando por más de ocho horas al día ya que es el único que cubre los gastos de educación, alimentación y pago de servicios básicos de su familia, también cuenta con una tienda de barrio.
El crédito lo requiere para aumentar su mercadería de la tienda ya que desea comprar productos por cantidad y de esta forma mejorar sus ingresos.
El sueño de René es construir su casa para dar más comodidad a su familia y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
René is married and has two school-aged children. The family lives in a house that they own. It has two rooms, walls made of brick, and a floor that is just earth. The house is in the Alto San Pedro area of La Paz city.

René is currently employed at a private business where he works eight hours per day. This is one income that the family has to pay for the children's education, food and other costs. René also has a small grocery store. 

René needs this loan in order to increase merchandise in his shop and buy products in bulk. With this loan he can increase his income. 

René's dream is to build a house so that his family may live more comfortably, and to improve their quality of life.

loans.use: to increase merchandise in his shop and buy products in bulk.

loans.name: Nora Guadalupe

texts.es: Nora de 30 años de edad vive en casa propia  con sus padres, ella se dedica a la agricultura, al cultivo del maíz y frijol, adicional a eso se dedica a la crianza de ganado, es una persona responsable y trabajadora, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas ayuda a solventar algunos gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, Nora solicita un crédito para la compra de fertilizante, herbicidas, abonos, etc. Y asi poder tener junto con su familia una mejor  calidad de vida.
texts.en: Nora is 30 years old and lives with her parents in a house that they own. Nora works in farming. She grows corn and beans. In addition she raises cattle. Nora is responsible and hard-working and is able to cover some household costs with her earnings. Nora is applying for a loan in order to buy fertlisers, manure, weed-killer and more. With these items Nora can enjoy a higher quality of life with her parents.

loans.use: to buy fertlisers, manure, weed-killer and more.

loans.name: Marcela Emperatriz

texts.es: Doña Marcela de 54 años de edad vive con su grupo familiar en casa propia, ella es una persona muy amable y trabajadora, se dedica a la pesca  artesanal desde hace varios años, comercializa sus pescados en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, con las ganancias que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, Doña Marcela solicita un crédito para la compra de trasmallos y redes para la pesca artesanal, para darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Marcela is 54 years old and lives in a house that she owns with her family. Marcela is very friendly and hard-working. She has been a fisherwoman for a number of years, and sells her fish in the different markets near her home. Marcela is able to cover some household costs with profits from sales. Marcela is applying for a loan in order to buy trammel and other nets for fishing. This will allow Marcela to offer her family a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy trammel and other nets.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia is a hardworking woman. She is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kangulumira in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past five years, Olivia has been working hard to manage her fuel / firewood business, which sells firewood and charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Olivia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal / firewood, and will help Olivia to generate greater profits and educate her child. Olivia hopes that in the future, she will be able to build a house. 

Olivia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal / firewood.

loans.name: Daysi Stefany

texts.es: Daysi vive en casa alquilada con su esposo, ella tiene una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia y es de fácil acceso para los clientes, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas y con la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar algunos gastos que se les presentan en su hogar, Daysi solicita un crédito para la compra de mas mercadería para su tienda como: golosinas, refrescos, aceites, huevos, azúcar, sopas, etc. y así poder seguir con su negocio y obtener mejores ganancias para tener junto con su esposo  una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Daysi lives in a rented house with her husband. She has a small shop in her home, which is easy for her customers to access. With profits from sales and help from her husband, Daysi is able to cover some household costs. Daysi is applying for a loan in order to buy more merchandise for her shop. She will buy sweets, soft drinks, oil, eggs, sugar, soups, and more. With these items she can then continue with her business and earn higher profits in order to enjoy a higher quality of life with her husband.

loans.use: to buy sweets, soft drinks, oil, eggs, sugar, soups, and more.

loans.name: Usaini

texts.en: Usaini is a Babban Gona farmer from kadanya Biyar. Usaini is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Usaini to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Usaini can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Usaini is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access yield-enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Usaini is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. He said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland." With this loan, Usaini will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Peter Goma

texts.en: Peter Goma is a maize farmer. As a Babban Gona member, Peter Goma is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Peter Goma can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Peter Goma is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season. Peter Goma is hopeful about what the future holds;he hopes that with the increased income as a result of high yield, he will finally be able to afford to send his children; Peace, faith and danlami to good schools. Peter Goma's dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and family”,he expressed.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en: Abubakar is a Babban Gona farmer from Kadanya Biyar. Abubakar expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Abubakar to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Abubakar can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Abubakar is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Abubakar will finally have enough money to make significant life changes, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland." With this loan, Abubakar will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more rice and groundnuts for resale

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is a maize farmer from Madaki Dutse. Mathew is driven by one goal: to “ensure my children are educated and have access to professional jobs.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Samaila to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. 
Mathew can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. With access to high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Mathew can reap up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I intend to provide a better education for my children." With this loan, Mathew will be able to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Isiyaku

texts.en: Isiyaku is a Babban Gona farmer from Kadanya Biyar. Isiyaku is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Isiyaku to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Isiyaku can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Isiyaku is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Isiyaku will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Isiyaku will be able to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a hardworking woman. She is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kangulumira in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past four years, Esther has been working hard to manage her fuel/firewood business, which sells firewood and charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Esther has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal, and will help Esther to generate greater profits and provide for the family. Esther hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a salon. 

Esther is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es: Marina de 53 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella se dedica a la venta de tortas y hamburguesas desde hace varios años, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en una zona muy transitada, por esa razón posee mucha clientela, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra sacar adelante a su familia, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de jamon, mortadela, salsa de tomate, pan, carne, curtido, mayonesa, etc. y asi poder darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Marina, 53, lives in her own house with her family.

She has earned a living for several years selling sandwiches and hamburgers.  She has a lot of customers because her business is located in a very busy area.  

She's requesting a loan to buy ham, mortadella, tomato sauce, bread, meat, "curtido" [pickled cabbage], mayonnaise, and so on.  That way she'll be able to give her family better financial stability.

loans.use: to buy ham, mortadella, tomato sauce, bread, meat, "curtido" [pickled cabbage], mayonnaise, etc.

loans.name: Heghine

texts.en:
Heghine lives in Yerevan with her husband and two children. She has been involved in the retail business. With the help of her husband, she trades in bedding and home supplies in one of the city markets.

Heghine and her husband, Artak, always knew that they wanted to start their own business to provide for their family and achieve their dreams. So, now the retail business that they are involved in helps them to gather income for the family's living. 

Heghine has now applied for this loan to be able to purchase bedding and other home supplies for selling in the store. Please help Heghine to expand the supplies for her store and increase sales.

loans.use: to pay for bedding and other home supplies for her store.

loans.name: Idi

texts.en: Idi is a maize farmer from Furana. Idi is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Idi to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Idi can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Idi is ambitious and aims to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. Idi is hoping that as a result of his yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Idi will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a maize farmer from Furana. Musa expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Musa to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Musa can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Musa is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Musa will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Musa will be able to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Nuhu

texts.en: Nuhu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Nuhu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children. Nuhu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Nuhu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Nuhu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Nuhu is not thinking about this year alone; he says that his long-term goal is to “provide a better education for my children." With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Micah

texts.en: Micah is a 28-year-old farmer from Dogonfako.  As a Babban Gona member, Micah is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Micah can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Micah is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Micah is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will be able to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Vicenta Antonia

texts.es: Vicenta de 48 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus hijos, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pupusas, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios años, posee mucha clientela  por los buenos precios y la amabilidad que tiene a la hora de vender, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo y con la ayuda de su esposo logan salir adelante con los gastos del hogar, Vicenta esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de quesillo, maíz, chicharron, etc. para seguir con su trabajo y poder tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Vicenta, 48, lives in her own house with her husband and her children.

She earns a living making and selling pupusas [stuffed tortillas].  Her business has been located in her home for several years.  She has a lot of customers because of her good prices and her friendliness when it comes time to make a sale.  They manage to get ahead on the household expenses with what she earns from her job and her husband's help.

Vicenta's requesting a loan to buy quesillo cheese, corn, pork cracklings, etc., so she can continue with her job and be able to have a better quality of life for herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy quesillo cheese, corn, pork cracklings, etc.

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.es: Teofilo esta casado tiene dos hijos y vive en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento donde paga un anticretico En ese lugar el cuarto de baño tiene problemas debido a una instalacion defectuosa  Teofilo trabaja como empleado publico y quiere un credito para hacer arreglos en el cuarto de baño Teofilo es el unico que contribuye en la economia familiar por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Teofilo is married and has two children. He lives in La Paz in a brick and cement house for which he pays a kind of rent. The bathroom isn't working properly because of an incorrect installation. Teofilo works as a public servant and is seeking a loan to fix the bathroom problem. He is the sole income earner in the family so he needs this assistance

loans.use: Make repairs to his bathroom

loans.name: Eliodoro

texts.es: Eliodoro esta casado tiene 3 hijos y vive en La Paz en una casa de acabado fino que es de su propiedad Eliodoro es jubilado y percibe una renta Eliodoro necesita el credito para pagar la instalacion de gas domiciliario en su casa, esta instalacion le ayudara a ahorrar mucho dinero Eliodoro es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Eliodoro  is married and has three children. He lives in a nice house which he owns. He is retired and receives a pension. Eliodoro now needs a loan to pay for his house to be connected to the gas system. This would save him a lot of money. He is the sole income earner in the family so he needs this assistance

loans.use: Pay for his house to be connected to the gas system

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: Maria de 53 años de edad, desde hace 5 años que posee una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia, vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus dos hijos, Maria esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos, azúcar, sopas, etc. para surtir su tienda y asi poderle dar a su familia una mejor calidad de vida sin limitación alguna.
texts.en:
María, 53, lives in her own home with her husband and her two children.  She has had a store in her house for five years.

María's requesting a loan to buy basic grains, snacks, soft drinks, sugar, soup, and so on, to stock her store.  That way she'll be able to give her family a better quality of life without any limitations whatsoever.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, snacks, soft drinks, sugar, soup, etc.

loans.name: Banco Mujer La Confianza Group

texts.es: Doña Violeta tiene 58 años de edad, es una mujer Nicaragüense sumamente trabajadora, hace más de 20 años la única opción en su vida en un país diferente para generar ingresos al hogar y poder salir adelante con su familia. Ella me comenta que desde niña observaba a su padre confeccionar zapatos por lo que decidió aprender y montar su propia zapatería con ayuda de sus hijos y esposo. Ya cuenta con una zapatería, una de las pocas de la zona donde ella vive; que se encuentra bien equipada con cualquier tipo de calzado que le soliciten sus vecinos. Hace dos años distribuye los zapatos a las diferentes tiendas, por lo que ella solicita el crédito con el fin de invertir en compra de materia prima para continuar confeccionando los diferentes calzados. Esto le ayuda a ella para generar ingresos al hogar, continuar colaborando con el bienestar de sus hijos y nietos. Doña Violeta es una mujer de gran carácter empresarial, muy agradecida con la atención que le brinda Fundación Mujer ya que la zona donde ella vive se considera como marginal, no es muy frecuentada, agradece la atención brindada y baja tasa de interés.
texts.en:
Violeta, 58 years old, is a notably hardworking Nicaraguan woman. 

Over 20 years ago, her only option in life was to live in a different country to generate household income and raise her family. She tells us that as a child she watched her father make shoes, so she decided to learn the craft and start her own shoe store with the help of her children and her husband. 

She already counts with the shoe store: one of the few within the area where she lives that is well stocked with all types of shoes that her clients may request.

For the last two years, she has been supplying shoes to different stores in the larger metropolitan area. As such, she is requesting a loan to invest in purchasing the raw materials needed to continue crafting together different shoes. 

This helps her generate revenue for the home so she can  provide for the welfare of her children and grandchildren. 

Violeta is a woman of great entrepreneurial nature and is very grateful for the assistance provided by Fundación Mujer, since the area where she lives is considered marginalized and is not frequently visited.  

She appreciates the loans offered at low interest rates.

loans.use: purchase raw materials for making shoes.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a maize farmer from Dogonfako. Ali is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Ali to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ali can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Ali is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access yield-enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Ali is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to expand his farmland. "Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community,” Ali said. With this loan, Ali will be able to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Idris

texts.en: Idris is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Idris joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Abba, Abdulsalam and Naima. Idris is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Idris will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he, would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Idris can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Idris said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family. Idris is not thinking about just this year.  In 5 years, he wants to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Jaime

texts.es: Jaime es soltero no tiene hijos y vive en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento que le pertenece a su madre Jaime trabja atendiendo un alojamiento  en un turno de 24 horas Jaime necesita un credito para renovar la indumentaria del lugar (comprar sabanas, edredones, colchones) debido a exigencias en el rubro Jaime es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Jaime is single and doesn't have any children. He lives in La Paz in a brick and cement house which belongs to his mother. He runs a hostel and works a 24-hour shift there. Jaime now needs a loan to buy bedding for the hostel (sheets, quilts, mattresses) which are much needed.  He is the sole income earner in the family so he needs this assistance.

loans.use: Buy much needed bedding (sheets, quilts, mattresses) for the hostel where he works

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
Immaculate is a hard-working woman. Immaculate is 17 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Immaculate has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Immaculate has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Immaculate to generate greater profits and gain personal development. Immaculate hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a poultry farm. 

Immaculate is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is a hardworking woman. Justine is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kangulumira in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 1 year, Justine has been working hard to manage her food stall, which sells tomatoes, onions, and bananas. 

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food items like cassava, eggplants, and avocado for the stall and will help Justine to generate greater profits and educate her child. Justine hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a wholesale shop. 

Justine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more food items like cassava, eggplants, and avocado for the stall.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a hard-working woman. Hellen is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 5 years, Hellen has been working hard to manage her soft drinks shop, where she sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Hellen has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more soft drinks for the shop, and will help Hellen to generate greater profits and educate her children. Hellen hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house for the family. 

Hellen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks for the shop.

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a hard-working woman. Madina is 19 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, Madina has been working hard to manage her salon, where she does hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Madina has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy salon items and soft drinks for the shop, and will help Madina to generate greater profits and increase her income. Madina hopes that in the future she will be able to get a bigger business. 

Madina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy salon items and soft drinks for the shop.

loans.name: Ajara's Group

texts.en:
Ajara's group is comprised of hard-working women. Ajara is 18 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 6 years, Ajara has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Ajara has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes, and will help Ajara to generate greater profits and ensure personal development. Ajara hopes that in the future she will be able to expand on the business. 

Ajara is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Musa joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Mobarak, Arda'u, and Musbahu. Musa is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Musa will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Musa can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Musa said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland.” Musa is not thinking about just this year. In 5 years, he wants to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Satyaperkas

texts.en:
Satyaperkas thanks all Kiva Lenders for helping him realize his long-terms goals. He has repaid his loan to Kiva lenders on time and could save some money for the purchase of his own plots. Satyaperkas could also expand his rice areas with the profits of this loan.

He approaches Seva MFI and Kiva lenders for another loan of SRD 10,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for the new season.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for the new season.

loans.name: Nyonko Do Group

texts.en:
The group Nyonko Do is composed of six persons, who live in the same district and are into grocery, dry fish, foodstuff, sewing accessories and secondhand clothing. 

The group’s representative, Mawukoenya, is 44 years old and married to a man named Wisdom. The couple have four children, all in school and in their care. She lives together with her husband and children. 

Mawukoenya ensures along with her husband that the diverse household expenses are covered. To do so, she has been selling a variety of foodstuff (maize, cassava and gari [cassava flour]) at her residence for about twelve years. She gets her supplies from a market of farmers. 

With the goal of bolstering her business, Mawukoenya and the other members are requesting a first loan from ID-Ghana. They promise to repay this loan duly and promptly.

loans.use: To buy a variety of foodstuff (maize, cassava and gari [cassava flour]) from the farmers and sell at her residence.

loans.name: Diego

texts.es:
Uno de los servicios públicos de mucho contacto con las personas de Sololá es el transporte público.  Las personas suben y bajan para transportarse de aquí para allá.  Cada una de ellas tienen su historia.  Pero también los transportistas o choferes también una variedad de historias personales y vivenciales.

Diego, de 37 años y padre de dos hijos, aprendió a ser chofer mientras vivía en los Estados Unidos y al venir a su ciudad de origen con sus ahorros compró un vehículo y se dedicó a este servicio público de transporte.

El ha solicitado un préstamo para darle el mantenimiento requerido por el vehículo y poder servir de esa manera a su ciudad, además que su actividad laboral es una fuente de ingresos para su familia.

Dentro de sus metas es lograr comprar otro vehículo y ampliar su negocio.  Y como resultado darles un mejor panorama económico a sus hijos.
texts.en:
One of the public services that is most important for the people of Sololá is that of public transportation. The people depend on this service in order to move from place to place. All the passengers have a story, as well as the drivers and chauffeurs. 

Diego is 37 and the father of two children. He learned how to be a driver while living in the United States. He returned to his home city and purchased a vehicle with his savings to dedicate himself to the public transportation service. 

He has requested this loan in order to maintain his vehicle and therefore serve his city. His work is necessary to provide for his family. In the future he wants to purchase another vehicle in order to grow his business and provide better opportunities for his children.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of his vehicle that he uses for his transportation service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, pure water and biscuits to expand her business.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel vive con sus padres; utiliza un ambiente como habitacion, tiene acceso a la cocina y una pequena sala de estar, se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Alto Sopocachi  de la ciudad de La Paz.  Es dependiente, trabaja en una optica como vendedor; Daniel percibe un salario fijo mensual y muy aparte de este trabajo el hace el servicio de transporte en su pequeña movilidad, para asi poder cubrir los gastos que tiene.
Daniel necesita el credito para pagar el mantenimiento de su vehiculo que usa como taxi 

El sueño de Daniel es formar una buena familia y criar a sus hijos en su propia casa, terminar sus estudios y de esta manera tener mayor estabilidad.
texts.en:
Daniel lives with his parents. He has a room of his own and has access to the kitchen and a small living room. The house is located in the Alto Sopocachi area of the city of La Paz. He works as a sales person for an optician where he receives a fixed monthly wage. In addition to this job he provides a taxi service on his small motorbike so he can cover his expenses.

Daniel needs a loan to pay for his vehicle to be serviced. His dreams are to have a nice family and raise children in his own home, finish his studies, and have greater financial stability.

loans.use: Pay for his taxi to be serviced

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a hardworking woman. Amina is 19 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 4 years, Amina has been working hard to manage her timber sale / shoes business, which deals in wood, timber and shoes. 

To help expand her business, Amina has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber and shoes and will help Amina to generate greater profits and for her personal development. Amina hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business. 

Amina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more timber and shoes.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is a hardworking woman. Prossy is 16 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 2 years, Prossy has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and will help Prossy to generate greater profits and expand on the business. Prossy hopes that in the future she will be able to have a profitable big business. 

Prossy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a hardworking woman. Halima is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children with neither of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Halima has been working hard to manage her clothing shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Halima has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and will help Halima to generate greater profits and provide for her family. Halima hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a saloon. 

Halima is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Phiona

texts.en:
Phiona is a hardworking woman. Phiona is 17 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 4 years, Phiona has been working hard to manage her charcoal business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Phiona has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal and will help Phiona to generate greater profits and for her personal development. Phiona hopes that in the future she will be able to save money for studies. 

Phiona is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Rehema's Group

texts.en:
Rehema's group is comprised of  hardworking women. Rehema is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past 2 years, Rehema has been working hard to manage her salon, which deals in hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Rehema has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy chemicals for the salon and will help Rehema to generate greater profits and educate her child. Rehema hopes that in the future she will be able to expand on the business. 

Rehema is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy chemicals for the salon.

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is a hardworking woman. Jalia is 20 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 3 years, Jalia has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Jalia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy food items for the business and will help Jalia to generate greater profits and educate her children. Jalia hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. 

Jalia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy food items for the business.

loans.name: Karla Vanesa

texts.es:
Karla de 42 años de edad, casada con tres hijos menores de edad, es originaria del Sauce lugar que está ubicado en la zona norte de la región. Esta joven mujer se caracteriza por ser trabajadora, responsables, con ganas de superación personal. Por la falta de empleo fijo ha recurrido al empleo informal para poder ayudar con los gastos de hogar y sacar adelante a sus hijos. Brindarles oportunidades de estudios, que lamentablemente ella no pudo cursar por falta de recursos económicos.
Gracias a sus ganas de salir adelante ella se dedica  a la venta de cosméticos de forma ambulante por encargo y en su casa de habitación. La rutina de trabajo de esta mujer es de unas doce horas diarias ofreciendo sus productos. como: rubor, vanidad, sombras, lápiz de ojos, delineador, desmaquillador, crema hidratantes. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de productos comestibles para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. y de esa forma cumplir metas establecidas como es poder mejorar su casa de habitación y  construirles habitaciones a sus hijos.  Karla agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es  Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en: Karla, 42, is married with three young children. She is originally from the northern region of Sauce. This young woman is known for being hardworking, responsible, and wanting to attain self-improvement. For lack of permanent employment, she has resorted to informal employment to help with the home and raise her children. She was given an opportunity to study but she could not attend due to lack of resources, unfortunately. Because of her desire to succeed, she sells cosmetics as a street vendor and from her home. The routine work for her is about twelve hours a day providing her products such as blush, shadows, eyeliner, eye pencils, make-up remover, and moisturizing cream. The purpose of this loan is to invest in working capital for her business to get a better income and meet her goals she's set to improve her home and a build a room for the children. Karla is grateful for the assistance provided by Kiva lenders to poor people in poor countries like Nicaragua to have a means of dignified work.

loans.use: to invest in cosmetics to sell out of her home

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is a hardworking woman. Scovia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her timber business, which sells wood and timber. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more wood and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and for her personal development. Scovia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand on the business. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more wood

loans.name: Priscillah

texts.en:
Pricillah is a 35-year-old lady, married to Eric and blessed with four children. She has been running a retail shop  for the last five years and gets a monthly income of KES 8,000.

She has applied for her first loan of KES 15,000 from Visionfund Kenya. She will use the loan to buy more stock of salt, sugar, and sweets for sale.

Pricillah will use the anticipated profits to provide for the family's basic needs and be financially stable in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of salt, sugar, and sweets for sale.

loans.name: Indo

texts.en:
Indo is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako. Indo is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Indo to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Indo can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
With access to high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed, Indo can yield up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. Indo is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, she will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked, she said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.” With this loan, Indo will be able to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Costence

texts.en:
Costence is a hard-working woman. Costence is 20 years old and lives in the town of Ishaka in the Kabwohe region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past year, Costence has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells cooking oil, sugar, salt, soap, bread, biscuits. 

To help expand her business, Costence has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy cooking oil, sugar, salt, soap, bread, biscuits, and will help Costence to generate greater profits and provide for her family. Costence hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a second shop. 

Costence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, sugar, salt, soap, bread, biscuits.

Monica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, sugar, salt, soap, bread, biscuits.

loans.name: Mammn

texts.en: Mammn is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Mammn joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Ibrahim, Harira and Yusifa. Mammn is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Mammn will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Mammn can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Mammn said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland. Mammn is not thinking about  just this year.  In 5 years, he wants to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

The loan will be used to buy materials for making more bricks, and will help Coreta to generate greater profits and add to the business. Coreta hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a saloon and build a house. 

Coreta is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.
